Text

﻿Helen with the high hand

[Arnold Bennett]73-arnold bennett

Chapter 1

BEGINNING OF [THE IDYLL

In the Five Towns]164-the idyll in the five towns human nature is reported to be so hard that [you]165-you can break stones on it . Yet sometimes it softens , and then [we]166-our have one of [our]166-our rare idylls of which [we]166-our are very proud , while pretending not to be . [The soft and delicate South]167-the soft and delicate south would possibly not esteem highly [our]166-our idylls , as such . Nevertheless they are [our]166-our idylls , idyllic for [us]166-our , and reminding [us]166-our , by certain symptoms , that though [we]166-our never cry there is concealed somewhere within [our]166-our bodies a fount of happy tears .

[The town park]168-the town park is an idyll in the otherwise prosaic municipal history of [the Borough of Bursley , which previously had never got nearer to romance]169-the borough of bursley , which previously had never got nearer to romance than [a Turkish bath]170-a turkish bath . [It]168-the town park was once waste ground covered with horrible rubbish - heaps , and made dangerous by [the imperfectly - protected shafts of disused coal - pits]171-the imperfectly - protected shafts of disused coal - pits . Now [you]165-you enter [it]168-the town park by emblazoned gates ; [it]168-the town park is surrounded by elegant railings ; fountains and cascades babble in it ; wild - fowl from [far countries]172-far countries roost in [it]168-the town park , on trees with long names ; tea is served in [it]168-the town park ; [brass bands]173-brass bands make music on [[its]168-the town park terraces]174-its terraces , and on [its]168-the town park highest terrace [[town]175-town [councillors]177-councillors]176-town councillors play bowls on billiard - table greens while casting proud glances on [the houses of [thirty thousand people]179-thirty thousand people spread out under the sweet influence of the gold angel that tops [the Town Hall spire]180-the town hall spire]178-the houses of thirty thousand people spread out under the sweet influence of the gold angel that tops the town hall spire . [The other four towns]181-the other four towns are apt to ridicule that gold angel , which for exactly fifty years has guarded [the borough]182-the borough and only been regilded twice . But ask [the plumber who last had the fearsome job of regilding it]183-the plumber who last had the fearsome job of regilding it whether it is a gold angel to be despised , and - [you]165-you will see !

[The other four towns]181-the other four towns are also apt to point to [[their]181-the other four towns own parks]185-their own parks when [Bursley]1-bursley mentions [[its]1-bursley park especially [Turnhill]2-turnhill , smallest and most conceited of [the Five]3-the five]186-its park especially turnhill , smallest and most conceited of the five ; but let [them]181-the other four towns show [a park whose natural situation equals that of Bursley 's park]187-a park whose natural situation equals that of bursley 's park . [You]165-you may tell [me]0-i that the terra - cotta constructions within [it]187-a park whose natural situation equals that of bursley 's park carry ugliness beyond a joke ; [you]165-you may tell [me]0-i that in spite of [the park]188-the park 's vaunted situation nothing can be seen from [it]187-a park whose natural situation equals that of bursley 's park save the chimneys and kilns of earthenware manufactories , the scaffoldings of pitheads , the ample dome of [[the rate - collector]189-the rate - collector 's offices]190-the rate - collector 's offices , [the railway]191-the railway , minarets of nonconformity , [sundry undulating square miles of monotonous house - roofs]192-sundry undulating square miles of monotonous house - roofs , the long scarves of black smoke which add such interest to the sky of [the Five Towns]193-the five towns - and , of course , the gold angel . But [I]0-i tell [you]165-you that before the days of [the park]188-the park [lovers]195-lovers had no place to walk in but [the cemetery]196-the cemetery ; not [the ancient churchyard of St. Luke 's]197-the ancient churchyard of st. luke 's [the rector]198-the rector would like to catch [them]195-lovers at [it]197-the ancient churchyard of st. luke 's ! - [the borough cemetery]199-the borough cemetery ! [One generation]200-one generation was forced to make love over the tombs of another - and such tombs ! - before the days of [the park]188-the park . That is the sufficient answer to any criticism of [the park]188-the park .

[The highest terrace of [the park]188-the park]203-the highest terrace of the park is a splendid expanse of gravel , ornamented with flower - beds . At one end is [the north bowling - green]205-the north bowling - green ; at the other is [the south bowling - green]206-the south bowling - green ; in the middle is [a terra - cotta and glass shelter]207-a terra - cotta and glass shelter ; and at intervals , against the terra - cotta balustrade , are arranged rustic seats from which [the aged]208-the aged , [the enamoured]209-the enamoured , and [the sedentary]210-the sedentary can enjoy the gold angel .

Between the southernmost seat and [the south bowling - green]206-the south bowling - green , on that Saturday afternoon , stood [Mr. James Ollerenshaw]74-james . [He]74-james was watching [a man who earned four - and - sixpence a day by gently toying from time to time with a roller on the polished surface of the green]212-a man who earned four - and - sixpence a day by gently toying from time to time with a roller on the polished surface of the green . [Mr. James Ollerenshaw]74-james 's age was sixty , but [he]74-james looked as if [he]74-james did not care . [His]74-james appearance was shabby ; but [he]74-james did not seem to mind . [He]74-james carried [his]74-james hands in the peculiar horizontal pockets of [his]74-james trousers , and stuck out [his]74-james figure , in a way to indicate that [he]74-james gave permission to [all]213-all to think of [him]74-james exactly what [they]213-all pleased . Those pockets were characteristic of the whole costume ; their very name is unfamiliar to the twentieth century . [They]213-all divide the garment by a fissure whose sides are kept together by many buttons , and a defection on the part of even a few buttons is apt to be inconvenient . [James Ollerenshaw]74-james was one of [the last persons in Bursley to defy fashion in the matter of pockets]214-the last persons in bursley to defy fashion in the matter of pockets . [His]74-james suit was of a strange hot colour - like a brick which , having become very dirty , has been imperfectly cleaned and then powdered with sand - made in a hard , eternal , resistless cloth , after a pattern which has not survived the apprenticeship of [[Five Towns]75-five towns ' tailors in [London]4-london]215-five towns ' tailors in london . Scarcely anywhere save on [the person of [James Ollerenshaw]74-james]216-the person of james ollerenshaw would [you]217-you see nowadays that cloth , that tint , those very short coat - tails , that curved opening of the waistcoat , or those trouser - pockets . The paper turned - down collar , and the black necktie of which only one square inch was ever visible , and the paper cuffs , which finished the tailor - made portion of [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james , still linger in sporadic profusion . [His]74-james low , flat - topped hat was faintly green , as though a delicate fungoid growth were just budding on its black . [His]74-james small feet were cloistered in small , thick boots of glittering brilliance . The colour of [his]74-james face matched that of [his]74-james suit . [He]74-james had no moustache and no whiskers , but a small , stiff grey beard was rooted somewhere under [his]74-james chin . [He]74-james had kept a good deal of [his]74-james hair . [He]74-james was [an undersized man]218-an undersized man , with short arms and legs , and all [his]74-james features - mouth , nose , ears , blue eyes - were small and sharp ; [his]74-james head , as an entirety , was small . [His]74-james thin mouth was always tightly shut , except when [he]74-james spoke . The general expression of [his]74-james face was one of suppressed , sarcastic amusement .

[He]74-james was always referred to as [Jimmy Ollerenshaw]74-james , and [he]74-james may strike [you]217-you as what is known as a " character , "[74-james] an oddity . [His]74-james sudden appearance at [a Royal Levée]219-a royal levée would assuredly have excited remark , and even in [Bursley]1-bursley [he]74-james diverged from the ordinary ; nevertheless , [I]0-i must expressly warn [you]217-you against imagining [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james as an oddity ; it is the most difficult thing in [the world]220-the world for [a man named [James]74-james]221-a man named james not to be referred to as [Jimmy]74-james . The temptation to [the public]222-the public is almost irresistible . Let [him]74-james have but a wart on [his]74-james nose , and [they]222-the public will regard it as sufficient excuse for yielding . [I]0-i do not think that [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james was consciously set down as an oddity in [[his]74-james native town]223-his native town . Certainly [he]74-james did not so set down [himself]74-james . Certainly [he]74-james was incapable of freakishness . By [the town]224-the town [he]74-james was respected . [His]74-james views on [cottage property]225-cottage property , the state of trade , and the finances of [the borough]182-the borough were listened to with a respectful absence of comment . [He]74-james was one of the few who had made [cottage property]225-cottage property pay . It was said [he]74-james owned [a mile of cottages in [Bursley]1-bursley and [Turnhill]2-turnhill]228-a mile of cottages in bursley and turnhill . It was said that , after [Ephraim Tellwright]76-ephraim tellwright , [he]74-james was [the richest man in [Bursley]1-bursley]229-the richest man in bursley . There was a slight resemblance of type between [Ollerenshaw]74-james and [Tellwright]76-ephraim tellwright . But [Tellwright]76-ephraim tellwright had buried [two wives]230-two wives , whereas [Ollerenshaw]74-james had never got within arm 's length of [a woman]231-a woman . [The town]224-the town much preferred [Ollerenshaw]74-james .

After having duly surveyed the majestic activities of [the ground - man on the bowling - green]233-the ground - man on the bowling - green , and having glanced at [his]74-james watch , [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james sat down on the nearest bench ; [he]74-james was waiting for [an opponent]234-an opponent , [the captain of [the bowling - club]236-the bowling - club]235-the captain of the bowling - club . It is exactly at the instant of [his]74-james downsitting that the drama about to be unfolded properly begins . Strolling along from the northern extremity of [the terrace]237-the terrace to the southern was [a young woman]238-a young woman . [This young woman]239-this young woman , as could be judged from [her]239-this young woman free and independent carriage , was such a creature as , having once resolved to do a thing , is not to be deterred from doing it by the caprices of [other people]240-other people . [She]239-this young woman had resolved - a resolution of no importance whatever - to seat [herself]239-this young woman on precisely [the southernmost bench of [the terrace]237-the terrace]241-the southernmost bench of the terrace . There was not , indeed , any particular reason why [she]239-this young woman should have chosen the southernmost bench ; but [she]239-this young woman had chosen [it]243-it . [She]239-this young woman had chosen [it]243-it , afar off , while [it]243-it was yet empty and [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james was on [his]74-james feet . When [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james dropped into a corner of [it]243-it [the girl]244-the girl 's first instinctive volition was to stop , earlier than [she]239-this young woman had intended , at one of the other seats .

Despite statements to the contrary , [man]245-man is so little like a sheep that when [he]245-man has a choice of benches in [a park]246-a park [he]245-man will always select an empty one . This rule is universal in [England]5-england and [Scotland]6-scotland , though elsewhere exceptions to it have been known to occur . But [the girl]244-the girl , being [a girl]248-a girl , and being [a girl who earned [her]244-the girl own living]249-a girl who earned her own living , and being [a girl who brought all conventions to the bar of [her]244-the girl reason and forced [them]251-them to stand trial [there]252-there]250-a girl who brought all conventions to the bar of her reason and forced them to stand trial there , said to [herself]244-the girl , proudly and coldly : " It would be absurd on [my]244-the girl part to change [my]244-the girl mind . [I]244-the girl meant to occupy that bench , and why should [I]244-the girl not ? There is amply sufficient space for [the man]1736-the man and [me]244-the girl too . [He]1736-the man has taken one corner , and [I]244-the girl will take the other . These notions that [girls]1737-girls have are silly . "[244-the girl] [She]244-the girl meant the notion that [she]244-the girl [herself]244-the girl had had .

So [she]244-the girl floated forward , charmingly and inexorably . [She]244-the girl was what in [the Five Towns]193-the five towns is called " a stylish piece of goods . "[244-the girl] [She]244-the girl wore a black - and - white frock , of a small check pattern , with a black belt and long black gloves , and [she]244-the girl held over [her]244-the girl serenity a black parasol richly flounced with black lace - a toilet unusual in [the district]254-the district , and as effective as it was unusual . [She]244-the girl knew how to carry it . [She]244-the girl was [a tall girl]255-a tall girl , and generously formed , with a complexion between fair and dark ; [her]244-the girl age , perhaps , about twenty - five . [She]244-the girl had the eye of [an empress]256-an empress - and not [an empress - consort]257-an empress - consort either , nor [an empress who trembles in secret at the rumour of cabals and intrigues]258-an empress who trembles in secret at the rumour of cabals and intrigues . Yes , considered as a decoration of [the terrace]237-the terrace , [she]244-the girl was possibly the finest , most dazzling thing that [Bursley]1-bursley could have produced ; and [Bursley]1-bursley doubtless regretted that it could only claim [her]244-the girl as [a daughter]260-a daughter by adoption .

Approaching , step by dainty and precise step , the seat invested by [Mr. James Ollerenshaw]74-james , [she]244-the girl arrived at the point whence [she]244-the girl could distinguish the features of [[her]244-the girl forestaller]261-her forestaller ; [she]244-the girl was somewhat short - sighted . [She]244-the girl gave no outward sign of fear , irresolution , cowardice . But if [she]244-the girl had not been more afraid of [her]244-the girl own contempt than of anything else in [the world]220-the world , [she]244-the girl would have run away ; [she]244-the girl would have ceased being [an empress]256-an empress and declined suddenly into [a scared child]264-a scared child . However , [her]244-the girl fear of [her]244-the girl own contempt kept [her]244-the girl spine straight , [her]244-the girl face towards the danger , and [her]244-the girl feet steadily moving .

" It 's not [my]244-the girl fault , "[244-the girl] [she]244-the girl said to [herself]244-the girl . " [I]244-the girl meant to occupy that bench , and occupy it [I]244-the girl will . What have [I]244-the girl to be ashamed of ? "[244-the girl]

And [she]244-the girl did occupy [that bench]265-that bench . [She]244-the girl contrived to occupy [it]265-that bench without seeing [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james . Each separate movement of [hers]244-the girl denied absolutely the existence of [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james . [She]244-the girl arranged [her]244-the girl dress , and [her]244-the girl parasol , and [her]244-the girl arms , and the exact angle of [her]244-the girl chin ; and there gradually fell upon [her]244-the girl that stillness which falls upon the figure of [a woman]231-a woman when [she]244-the girl has definitively adopted an attitude in the public eye . [She]244-the girl was gazing at the gold angel , a mile off , which flashed in the sun . But what a deceptive stillness was that stillness ! A hammer was hammering away under [her]244-the girl breast with what seemed to [her]244-the girl a reverberating sound . Strange that that hammering did not excite attention throughout [the park]188-the park ! Then [she]244-the girl had the misfortune to think of the act of blushing . [She]244-the girl violently willed not to blush . But [her]244-the girl blood was too much for [her]244-the girl . It displayed itself in the most sanguinary manner first in the centre of each cheek , and it increased its area of conquest until the whole of [her]244-the girl visible skin - even the back of [her]244-the girl neck and [her]244-the girl lobes - had rosily yielded . And [she]244-the girl was [one of [[your]269-your girls]270-your girls who never blush ! The ignominy of it ! To blush because [she]244-the girl found [herself]244-the girl within thirty inches of [a man]271-a man , [an old man , with whom [she]244-the girl had never in [her]244-the girl life]272-an old man , with whom she had never in her life exchanged a single word]268-one of your girls who never blush ! the ignominy of it ! to blush because she found herself within thirty inches of a man , an old man , with whom she had never in her life exchanged a single word !

Contents Chapter 2

AN AFFAIR OF THE SEVENTIES

Having satisfied [her]244-the girl obstinacy by sitting down on the seat of [her]244-the girl choice , [she]244-the girl might surely - one would think - have ended a mysteriously difficult situation by rising again and departing , of course with due dignity . But no ! [She]244-the girl could not ! [She]244-the girl wished to do so , but [she]244-the girl could not command [her]244-the girl limbs . [She]244-the girl just sat there , in horridest torture , like a stoical fly on a pin - one of those flies that pretend that nothing hurts . The agony might have been prolonged to centuries had not an extremely startling and dramatic thing happened - the most startling and dramatic thing that ever happened either to [James Ollerenshaw]74-james or to [the young woman]273-the young woman . [James Ollerenshaw]74-james spoke , and [I]0-i imagine that [nobody]274-nobody was more surprised than [James Ollerenshaw]74-james by [his]74-james brief speech , which slipped out of [him]74-james quite unawares . What [he]74-james said was :

" Well , [lass]1738-lass , how goes it , like ? "[74-james]

If [the town]224-the town could have heard [him]74-james , [the town]224-the town would have rustled from boundary to boundary with agitated and delicious whisperings .

[The young woman]273-the young woman , instead of being justly incensed by this monstrous molestation from [an aged villain who had not been introduced to [her]273-the young woman]278-an aged villain who had not been introduced to her , gave a little jump as though relieved from the spell of an enchantment , and then deliberately turned and faced [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james . [She]273-the young woman also smiled , amid [her]273-the young woman roses .

" Very well indeed , thank [you]74-james , "[273-the young woman] [she]273-the young woman replied , primly , but nicely .

Upon this , [[they]279-they both of [them]279-they]280-they both of them sought to recover - from an affair that had occurred in the late seventies .

In the late seventies [James Ollerenshaw]74-james had been [a young - old man of nearly thirty]281-a young - old man of nearly thirty . [He]74-james had had [a stepbrother]282-a stepbrother , much older and much poorer than [himself]74-james , and [the stepbrother]283-the stepbrother had died , leaving [a daughter]260-a daughter , named [Susan]78-susan , almost , but not quite , in a state of indigence . [The stepbrother]283-the stepbrother and [James]74-james had not been on terms of effusive cordiality . But [James]74-james was perfectly ready to look after [Susan]78-susan , [[his]74-james stepniece]286-his stepniece . [Susan]78-susan , aged seventeen years , was , however , not perfectly ready to be looked after . [She]78-susan had a little money , and [she]78-susan earned a little by painting asters on toilet ware , and the chit was very rude to [[her]78-susan stepuncle]287-her stepuncle . In less than a year [she]78-susan had married [a youth of twenty]288-a youth of twenty , who apparently had not in [him]288-a youth of twenty even the rudiments of worldly successfulness . [James Ollerenshaw]74-james did [his]74-james avuncular duty by formally and grimly protesting against the marriage . But what authority has [a stepuncle]289-a stepuncle ? [Susan]78-susan defied [him]74-james , with a maximum of unforgettable impoliteness ; and [she]78-susan went to live with [[her]78-susan husband]290-her husband at [Longshaw]7-longshaw , which is at [the other end of [the Five Towns]193-the five towns]291-the other end of the five towns . The fact became public that a solemn quarrel existed between [James]74-james and [Susan]78-susan , and that [each of [them]294-them]293-each of them had sworn not to speak until [the other]295-the other spoke . [James]74-james would have forgiven , if [she]78-susan had hinted at reconciliation . And , hard as it is for [youth]296-youth to be in the wrong , [Susan]78-susan would have hinted at reconciliation if [James]74-james had not been so rich . The riches of [James]74-james offended [Susan]78-susan 's independence . Not for [millions]297-millions would [she]78-susan have exposed [herself]78-susan to the suspicion that [she]78-susan had broken [her]78-susan oath because [[her]78-susan stepuncle]287-her stepuncle was [a wealthy and childless man]299-a wealthy and childless man . [She]78-susan was , of course , wrong . Nor was this [her]78-susan only indiscretion . [She]78-susan was so ridiculously indiscreet as to influence [[her]78-susan husband]290-her husband in such a way that [he]290-her husband actually succeeded in life . Had [James]74-james perceived [them]301-them to be struggling in poverty , [he]74-james might conceivably have gone over to [them]301-them and helped [them]301-them , in an orgy of forgiving charity . But the success of [young Rathbone]79-helen falsified [his]74-james predictions utterly , and was , further , an affront to [him]74-james . Thus the quarrel slowly crystallised into a permanent estrangement , a passive feud . [Everybody]302-everybody got thoroughly accustomed to it , and thought nothing of it , it being a social phenomenon not at all unique of its kind in [the Five Towns]193-the five towns . When , fifteen years later , [Rathbone]79-helen died in mid - career , [people]304-people thought that the feud would end . But it did not . [James]74-james wrote a letter of condolence to [[his]74-james niece]305-his niece , and even sent it to [Longshaw]80-longshaw by special messenger in [the tramcar]306-the tramcar ; but [he]74-james had not heard of the death until the day of the funeral , and [Mrs. Rathbone]81-mrs. rathbone did not reply to [his]74-james letter . [Her]81-mrs. rathbone independence and sensitiveness were again in the wrong . [James]74-james did no more . [You]307-you could not expect [him]74-james to have done more . [Mrs. Rathbone]81-mrs. rathbone , like [many widows of [successful men]309-successful men]308-many widows of successful men , was " left poorly off . "[81-mrs. rathbone] But [she]81-mrs. rathbone " managed . "[81-mrs. rathbone] Once , five years before the scene on [the park terrace]310-the park terrace , [Mrs. Rathbone]81-mrs. rathbone and [James]74-james had encountered [one another]311-one another by hazard on [the platform of [Knype Railway Station]8-knype railway station]312-the platform of knype railway station . [Destiny]82-destiny hesitated while [Susan]78-susan waited for [James]74-james 's recognition and [James]74-james waited for [Susan]78-susan 's recognition . [Both of [them]313-both of them]313-both of them waited too long . [Destiny]82-destiny averted its head and drew back , and [the relatives]314-the relatives passed on [their]314-the relatives ways without speaking . [James]74-james observed with interest [a girl of twenty by [Susan]78-susan 's side]315-a girl of twenty by susan 's side - [[her]81-mrs. rathbone daughter]316-her daughter . [This daughter of [Susan]78-susan 's]317-this daughter of susan 's was now sharing the park bench with [him]74-james . Hence the hidden drama of [their]313-both of them meeting , of [his]74-james speech , of [her]317-this daughter of susan 's reply .

" And what 's [your]317-this daughter of susan 's name , [lass]1738-lass ? "[317-this daughter of susan 's]

" [Helen]79-helen . "[317-this daughter of susan 's]

" [Helen]79-helen what ? "[317-this daughter of susan 's]

" [Helen]79-helen , great - stepuncle , "[317-this daughter of susan 's] said [she]317-this daughter of susan 's . [He]74-james laughed ; and [she]317-this daughter of susan 's laughed also . The fact was that [he]74-james had been aware of [her]317-this daughter of susan 's name , vaguely . It had come to [him]74-james , on the wind , or by some bird 's wing , although [none of [[his]74-james acquaintances]319-his acquaintances]318-none of his acquaintances had been courageous enough to speak to [him]74-james about the affair of [Susan]78-susan for quite twenty years past . [Longshaw]80-longshaw is as far from [Bursley]1-bursley , in some ways , as [San Francisco]9-san francisco from [New York]10-new york . There are [people in [Bursley]1-bursley who do not know the name of [the Mayor of [Longshaw]7-longshaw]80-longshaw]320-people in bursley who do not know the name of the mayor of longshaw - who make a point of not knowing it . Yet news travels even from [Longshaw]7-longshaw to [Bursley]1-bursley , by mysterious channels ; and [Helen Rathbone]79-helen 's name had so travelled . [James Ollerenshaw]74-james was glad that [she]79-helen was just [Helen]79-helen . [He]74-james had been afraid that there might be something fancy between [Helen]79-helen and [Rathbone]79-helen - something expensive and aristocratic that went with [her]79-helen dress and [her]79-helen parasol . [He]74-james illogically liked [her]79-helen for being called merely [Helen]79-helen - as if the credit were [hers]79-helen ! [Helen]79-helen was an old Ollerenshaw name - [[his]74-james grandmother]321-his grandmother 's who had been attached to [the household of [Josiah Wedgwood]83-josiah wedgwood]322-the household of josiah wedgwood , and [[his]74-james aunt]323-his aunt 's . [Helen]79-helen was historic in [his]74-james mind . And , further , it could not be denied that [Rathbone]79-helen was [a fine old Five Towns name]324-a fine old five towns name too .

[He]74-james was very illogical that afternoon ; [he]74-james threw over the principles of a lifetime , arguing from particulars to generals exactly like [a girl]248-a girl . [He]74-james had objected , always , to the expensive and the aristocratic . [He]74-james was proud of [his]74-james pure plebeian blood , as [many plebeians]326-many plebeians are ; [he]74-james gloried in it . [He]74-james disliked show , with a calm and deep aversion . [He]74-james was [a plain man with a simple , unostentatious taste for money]327-a plain man with a simple , unostentatious taste for money . The difference between [Helen]79-helen 's name and [her]79-helen ornamental raiment gave [him]74-james pleasure in the name . But [he]74-james had not been examining [her]79-helen for more than half a minute when [he]74-james began to find pleasure in [her]79-helen rich clothes rich , that is , to [him]74-james ! . Quite suddenly [he]74-james , at the age of sixty , abandoned without an effort [his]74-james dear prejudice against fine feathers , and began , for the first time , to take joy in sitting next to [a pretty and well - dressed woman]328-a pretty and well - dressed woman . And all this , not from any broad , philosophic perception that fine feathers have their proper part in the great scheme of cosmic evolution ; but because the check dress suited [her]79-helen , and the heavy , voluptuous parasol suited [her]79-helen , and the long black gloves were inexplicably effective . [Women]329-women grow old ; [women]329-women cease to learn ; but [men]331-men , never .

As for [Helen]79-helen , [she]79-helen liked [him]74-james . [She]79-helen had liked [him]74-james for five years , ever since [[her]79-helen mother]332-her mother had pointed [him]74-james out on [the platform of [Knype Railway Station]8-knype railway station]312-the platform of knype railway station . [She]79-helen saw [him]74-james closer now . [He]74-james was older than [she]79-helen had been picturing [him]74-james ; indeed , the lines on [his]74-james little , rather wizened face , and the minute sproutings of grey - white hair in certain spots on [his]74-james reddish chin , where [he]74-james had shaved [himself]74-james badly , caused [her]79-helen somehow to feel quite sad . [She]79-helen thought of [him]74-james as " [a dear old thing]1740-a dear old thing , "[74-james] and then as " [a dear old darling]1741-a dear old darling . "[79-helen] Yes , old , very old ! Nevertheless , [she]79-helen felt maternal towards [him]74-james . [She]79-helen felt that [she]79-helen was much wiser than [he]74-james was , and that [she]79-helen could teach [him]74-james a great deal . [She]79-helen saw very clearly how wrong [he]74-james and [[her]79-helen mother]332-her mother had been , with [their]335-their stupidly terrific quarrel ; and the notion of all the happiness which [he]74-james had missed , in [his]74-james solitary , unfeminised , bachelor existence , nearly brought into [her]79-helen eyes tears of a quick and generous sympathy .

[He]74-james , blind and [shabby ancient]336-shabby ancient , had no suspicion that [his]74-james melancholy state and the notion of all the happiness [he]74-james had missed had tinged with sorrow the heart within the frock , and added a dangerous humidity to the glance under the sunshade . It did not occur to [him]74-james that [he]74-james was an object of pity , nor that a vast store of knowledge was waiting to be poured into [him]74-james . [The aged , self - satisfied wag - beard]337-the aged , self - satisfied wag - beard imagined that [he]74-james had conducted [his]74-james career fairly well . [He]74-james knew [no one with whom [he]74-james would have changed places]338-no one with whom he would have changed places . [He]74-james regarded [Helen]79-helen as an extremely agreeable little thing , with [her]79-helen absurd air of being grown - up . Decidedly in five years [she]79-helen had tremendously altered . Five years ago [she]79-helen had been gawky . Now . . . Well , [he]74-james was proud of [her]79-helen . [She]79-helen had called [him]74-james great - stepuncle , thus conferring on [him]74-james a sort of part - proprietorship in [her]79-helen ; and [he]74-james was proud of [her]79-helen . [The captain of the bowling - club]235-the captain of the bowling - club came along , and [James Ollerenshaw]74-james gave [him]74-james just such a casual nod as [he]74-james might have given to [a person of no account]340-a person of no account . The nod seemed to say : " Match this , if [you]74-james can . It 's [mine]74-james , and there 's nothing in [the town]224-the town to beat it . [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter [herself]84-mrs. prockter has n't got more style than this . "[74-james] Of this [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter , more later .

[Helen]79-helen soon settled down into a condition of ease , which put an end to blushing . [She]79-helen knew [she]79-helen was admired .

" What are [you]79-helen doing [i]74-james ' [Bosley]18-bosley ? "[74-james] [James]74-james demanded .

" [I]79-helen 'm living [i]79-helen ' [Bosley]18-bosley , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen retorted , smartly .

" Living here ! "[74-james] [He]74-james stopped , and [his]74-james hard old heart almost stopped too . If not in mourning , [she]79-helen was in semi - mourning . Surely [Susan]78-susan had not had the effrontery to die , away in [Longshaw]7-longshaw , without telling [him]74-james !

" [Mother]1743-mother has married again , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen , lightly .

" Married ! "[74-james] [He]74-james was staggered . The wind was knocked out of [him]74-james .

" Yes . And gone to [Canada]11-canada ! "[79-helen] [Helen]79-helen added .

[You]341-you pick up [your]341-you paper in the morning , and idly and slowly peruse the advertisements on the first page , forget it , eat some bacon , grumble at [the youngest boy]342-the youngest boy , open the paper , read the breach of promise case on page three , drop it , and ask [[your]341-you wife]343-your wife for more coffee - hot - glance at [your]341-you letters again , then reopen the paper at the news page , and find that [the Tsar of [Russia]12-russia]344-the tsar of russia has been murdered , and [a few American cities]345-a few american cities tumbled to fragments by an earthquake - [you]341-you know how [you]341-you feel then . [James Ollerenshaw]74-james felt like that . [The captain of [the bowling - club]236-the bowling - club]235-the captain of the bowling - club , however , poising a bowl in [his]235-the captain of the bowling - club right hand , and waiting for [James Ollerenshaw]74-james to leave [his]235-the captain of the bowling - club silken dalliance , saw nothing but [an old man]348-an old man and [a young woman]238-a young woman sitting on a Corporation seat .

Contents Chapter 3

MARRYING OFF [A MOTHER]350-a mother

" Yes , "[79-helen] said [Helen Rathbone]79-helen , " [mother]1743-mother fell in love . Do n't [you]74-james think it was funny ? "[79-helen]

" That 's as may be , "[74-james] [James Ollerenshaw]74-james replied , in [his]74-james quality of [the wiseacre who is accustomed to be sagacious on the least possible expenditure of words]351-the wiseacre who is accustomed to be sagacious on the least possible expenditure of words .

" [We]1745-we both thought it was awfully funny , "[79-helen] [Helen]79-helen said .

" Both ? Who else is there ? "[74-james]

" Why , [mother]1743-mother and [I]74-james , of course ! [We]1745-we used to laugh over it . [You]1747-you see , [mother]1743-mother is a very simple creature . And [she]238-a young woman 's only forty - four . "[74-james]

" [She]238-a young woman 's above forty - four , "[74-james] [James]74-james corrected .

" [She]238-a young woman told [me]79-helen [she]238-a young woman was thirty - nine five years ago , "[79-helen] [Helen]79-helen protested .

" Did [she]238-a young woman tell [ye]74-james [she]238-a young woman was forty , four years ago ? "[79-helen]

" No . At least , [I]74-james do n't remember . "[74-james]

" Did [she]238-a young woman ever tell [ye]74-james [she]238-a young woman was forty ? "[79-helen]

" No . "[74-james]

" Happen [she]238-a young woman 's not such a simple creature as [ye]74-james thought for , [[my]74-james lass]1749-my lass , "[74-james] observed [James Ollerenshaw]74-james .

" [You]74-james do n't mean to infer , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen , with cold dignity , " that [[my]79-helen mother]1750-my mother would tell [me]79-helen a lie ?[79-helen]

" All as [I]74-james mean is that [Susan]78-susan was above thirty - nine five years ago , and [I]74-james can prove it . [I]74-james had to get [her]78-susan birth certificate when [[her]78-susan father]1751-her father died , and [I]74-james fancy [I]74-james 've got it by [me]74-james yet . "[74-james] And [his]74-james eyes added : " So much for that point . One to [me]74-james . "[74-james]

[Helen]79-helen blushed and frowned , and looked up into the darkling heaven of [her]79-helen parasol ; and then it occurred to [her]79-helen that [her]79-helen wisest plan would be to laugh . So [she]79-helen laughed . [She]79-helen laughed in almost precisely the same manner as [James]74-james had heard [Susan]78-susan laugh thirty years previously , before love had come into [Susan]78-susan 's life like a shell into a fortress , and finally blown [their]352-their fragile relations all to pieces . A few minutes earlier the sight of great - stepuncle [James]74-james had filled [Helen]79-helen with sadness , and [he]74-james had not suspected it . Now [her]79-helen laugh filled [James]74-james with sadness , and [she]79-helen did not suspect it . In [his]74-james sadness , however , [he]74-james was glad that [she]79-helen laughed so naturally , and that the sombre magnificence of [her]79-helen dress and [her]79-helen gloves and parasol did not prevent [her]79-helen from opening [her]79-helen rather large mouth and showing [her]79-helen teeth .

" It was just like [mother]1743-mother to tell [me]79-helen fibs about [her]79-helen age , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen , generously it is always interesting to observe the transformation of a lie into a fib . " And [I]79-helen shall write and tell [her]79-helen [she]79-helen 's a horrid mean thing . [I]79-helen shall write to [her]79-helen this very night . "[79-helen]

" So [Susan]78-susan 's gone and married again ! "[74-james] [James]74-james murmured , reflectively .

[Helen]79-helen now definitely turned the whole of [her]79-helen mortal part towards [James]74-james , so that [she]79-helen fronted [him]74-james , and [her]79-helen feet were near [his]74-james . [He]74-james also turned , in response to this diplomatic advance , and leant [his]74-james right elbow on the back of the seat , and [his]74-james chin on [his]74-james right palm . [He]74-james put [his]74-james left leg over [his]74-james right leg , and thus [his]74-james left foot swayed like a bird on a twig within an inch of [Helen]79-helen 's flounce . The parasol covered the faces of [the just and the unjust impartially]353-the just and the unjust impartially .

" [I]79-helen suppose [you]74-james do n't know [a farmer named [Bratt]86-mr. bratt that used to have [a farm near [Sneyd]15-sneyd - road]1754-a farm near sneyd]1753-a farmer named bratt that used to have a farm near sneyd ? "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen .

" [I]74-james 'll not deny it , "[74-james] said [James]74-james .

" Why not ? "[79-helen]

" What ! [Th ' farmer]1767-th ' farmer saved [her]89-mother from a mad bull , and [she]89-mother fell in love with [him]1767-th ' farmer ? [He]1767-th ' farmer 's younger than [her]89-mother , [I]74-james lay ! "[74-james]

" How did [you]74-james know that ? "[79-helen] [Helen]79-helen questioned . " Besides , [he]1767-th ' farmer is n't . [They]1768-they 're just the same age . "[79-helen]

" Forty - four ? "[74-james] Perceiving delicious danger in [the virgin]354-the virgin 's face , [James]74-james continued before [she]79-helen could retort , " [I]74-james hope [Susan]78-susan was n't gored ? "[74-james]

" [You]74-james 're quite wrong . [You]74-james 're jumping to conclusions , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen , with an air of indulgence that would have been exasperating had it not been enchanting . " Things do n't happen like that except in novels . "[79-helen]

" Have n't [you]79-helen ? How interesting ! "[74-james]

" But [I]74-james 've known [a woman]231-a woman knocked down by a bull . "[74-james]

" Well , anyhow , [mother]1743-mother was n't knocked down by a bull . But there was a mad bull running down [the street]1771-the street ; it had escaped from [the market]1772-the market . And [Mr. Bratt]86-mr. bratt was walking [home]1773-home , and the bull was after [him]86-mr. bratt like a shot . [Mother]89-mother was looking out of the window , and [she]89-mother saw what was going on . So [she]89-mother rushed to the front door and opened it , and called to [Mr. Bratt]86-mr. bratt to run in and take shelter . And [they]1774-them only just got the door shut in time . "[74-james]

" Why , [I]74-james came [home]1773-home from [school]1776-school and found [them]1774-them having tea together . "[74-james]

" And ninety year between [them]1774-them ! "[74-james] [James]74-james reflected .

" Then [Mr. Bratt]86-mr. bratt called every week . [He]86-mr. bratt was [a widower]1777-a widower , with [no children]1778-no children . "[74-james]

" It could n't [ha]1779-ha ' been better , "[74-james] said [James]74-james .

" Oh yes , it could , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen . " Because [I]79-helen had the greatest difficulty in marrying [them]1774-them ; in fact , at one time [I]79-helen thought [I]79-helen should never do it . [I]79-helen 'm always in the right , and [mother]1743-mother 's always in the wrong . [She]1743-mother 's admitted that for years . [She]1743-mother 's had to admit it . Yet [she]1743-mother would go [her]1743-mother own way . Nothing would ever cure [mother]1743-mother . "[79-helen]

" [She]1743-mother used to talk just like that of [[your]79-helen grandfather]1782-your grandfather , "[74-james] said [James]74-james . " [Susan]78-susan always reckoned as [she]1743-mother 'd got more than [her]1743-mother fair share of sense . "[74-james]

" [I]79-helen do n't think [she]1743-mother thinks that now , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen , calmly , as if to say : " At any rate [I]79-helen 've cured [her]1743-mother of that . "[79-helen] Then [she]79-helen went on : " [You]79-helen see , [Mr. Bratt]86-mr. bratt had sold [[his]86-mr. bratt farm]1783-his farm - could n't make it pay - and [he]86-mr. bratt was going out to [Manitoba]16-manitoba . [He]86-mr. bratt said [he]86-mr. bratt would stop in [England]5-england . [She]89-mother was quite right there , "[79-helen] [Helen]79-helen admitted , with careful justice . " But then [she]89-mother said [she]89-mother would n't marry [him]86-mr. bratt and go out to [Manitoba]16-manitoba , because of leaving [me]79-helen alone here to look after [myself]79-helen ! Can [you]74-james imagine such a reason ?[79-helen]

[James]74-james merely raised [his]74-james head quickly several times . The gesture meant whatever [Helen]79-helen preferred that it should mean .

" The idea ! "[79-helen] [she]79-helen continued . " As if [I]79-helen had n't looked after [mother]1743-mother and kept [her]1743-mother in order , and [myself]79-helen , too , for several years ! No . [She]89-mother would n't marry [him]86-mr. bratt and go out there ! And [she]89-mother would n't marry [him]86-mr. bratt and stay [here]1785-here ! [She]89-mother actually began to talk all the usual conventional sort of stuff , [you]74-james know - about how [she]89-mother had no right to marry again , and [she]89-mother did n't believe in second marriages , and about [her]89-mother duty to [me]79-helen . And so on . [You]74-james know . [I]79-helen reasoned with [her]89-mother - [I]79-helen explained to [her]89-mother that probably [she]89-mother had another thirty years to live . [I]79-helen told [her]89-mother [she]89-mother was quite young . [She]89-mother is . And why should [she]89-mother make [herself]89-mother permanently miserable , and [Mr. Bratt]86-mr. bratt , and [me]79-helen , merely out of a quite mistaken sense of duty ? No use ! [I]79-helen tried everything [I]79-helen could . No use ! "[79-helen]

" [She]89-mother was too much for [ye]79-helen ? "[79-helen]

" Oh , no ! "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen , condescendingly . " [I]79-helen 'd made up [my]79-helen mind . [I]79-helen arranged things with [Mr. Bratt]86-mr. bratt . [He]86-mr. bratt quite agreed with [me]79-helen . [He]86-mr. bratt took out a licence at [the registrar 's]1786-the registrar 's , and one Saturday morning - it had to be a Saturday , because [I]79-helen 'm busy all the other days - [I]79-helen went out with [mother]1743-mother to buy the meat and things for [Sunday]90-sunday 's dinner , and [I]79-helen got [her]89-mother into [[the registrar]1788-the registrar 's office]1789-the registrar 's office - and , well , there [she]89-mother was ! Now , what do [you]74-james think ? "[79-helen]

" What ? "[79-helen]

" [Her]89-mother last excuse was that [she]89-mother could n't be married because [she]89-mother was wearing [her]89-mother third - best hat . Do n't [you]74-james think it 's awfully funny ? "[79-helen]

" That 's as may be , "[74-james] said [James]74-james . " When was all this ? "[74-james]

" Just recently , "[79-helen] [Helen]79-helen answered . " [They]1790-they sailed from [Glasgow]17-glasgow last Thursday but two . And [I]79-helen 'm expecting a letter by every post to say that [they]1790-they 've arrived safely . "[79-helen]

" And [Susan]78-susan 's left [you]74-james to take care of [yourself]74-james ! "[79-helen]

" Now , please do n't begin talking like [mother]1743-mother , "[79-helen] [Helen]79-helen said , frigidly . " [I]79-helen 've certainly got less to take care of now than [I]79-helen had . [Mother]89-mother quite saw that . But what difficulty [I]79-helen had in getting [her]89-mother off , even after [I]79-helen 'd safely married [her]89-mother ! " [You]74-james wo n't ? "[79-helen]

" No . [I]79-helen do n't see [myself]79-helen on [a farm in [Manitoba]16-manitoba]1792-a farm in manitoba . Do [you]74-james ? "[79-helen]

Contents Chapter 4

[INVITATION TO TEA]93-invitation to tea

[They]356-they were most foolishly happy as [they]356-they sat there on the bench , [this man whose dim eyes ought to have been waiting placidly for the ship of death]357-this man whose dim eyes ought to have been waiting placidly for the ship of death to appear above the horizon , and [this young girl who imagined that [she]358-this young girl who imagined that she knew all about life and the world knew all about life and [the world]220-the world]358-this young girl who imagined that she knew all about life and the world . When [I]0-i say that [they]356-they were foolishly happy , [I]0-i of course mean that [they]356-they were most wisely happy . Each of [them]356-they , being gifted with common sense , and with a certain imperviousness to sentimentality which invariably accompanies common sense , [they]356-they did not mar the present by regretting the tragic stupidity of a long estrangement ; [they]356-they did not mourn over wasted years that could not be recalled . It must be admitted , in favour of [the Five Towns]193-the five towns , that when [its inhabitants]361-its inhabitants spill milk [they]361-its inhabitants do not usually sit down on [the pavement]362-the pavement and adulterate the milk with [their]361-its inhabitants tears . [They]361-its inhabitants pass on . Such passing on is termed callous and cold - hearted in [the rest of [England]5-england]363-the rest of england , which loves to sit down on pavements and weep into irretrievable milk .

Nor did [Helen]79-helen and [her]79-helen great - stepuncle mar the present by worrying about the future ; it never occurred to [them]356-they to be disturbed by the possibility that milk not already spilt might yet be spilt .

[Helen]79-helen had been momentarily saddened by private reflections upon what [James Ollerenshaw]74-james had missed in [his]74-james career ; and [James]74-james had been saddened , somewhat less , by reminiscences which had sprung out of [Helen]79-helen 's laugh . But [their]356-they melancholies had rapidly evaporated in the warmth of the unexpected encounter . [They]356-they liked [one another]311-one another . [She]79-helen liked [him]74-james because [he]74-james was old and dry ; and because [he]74-james had a short laugh , and a cynical and even wicked gleam of the eye that pleased [her]79-helen ; and because there was an occasional tone in [his]74-james voice that struck [her]79-helen as deliciously masculine , ancient , and indulgent ; and because [he]74-james had spoken to [her]79-helen first ; and because [his]74-james gaze wandered with an admiring interest over [her]79-helen dress and up into the dome of [her]79-helen sunshade ; and because [he]74-james put [his]74-james chin in [his]74-james palm and leant [his]74-james head towards [her]79-helen ; and because the skin of [his]74-james hand was so crinkled and glossy . And [he]74-james liked [her]79-helen because [she]79-helen was so exquisitely fresh and candid , so elegant , so violent and complete a contrast to [James Ollerenshaw]74-james ; so absurdly sagacious and sure of [herself]79-helen , and perhaps because of a curve in [her]79-helen cheek , and a mysterious suggestion of eternal enigma in [her]79-helen large and liquid eye . When [she]79-helen looked right away from [him]74-james , as [she]79-helen sometimes did in the conversation , the outline of [her]79-helen soft cheek , which drew in at the eye and swelled out again to the temple , resembled a map of [the coast of [some smooth , romantic country]366-some smooth , romantic country not mentioned in geographies]365-the coast of some smooth , romantic country not mentioned in geographies . When [she]79-helen looked at [him]74-james - well , the effect on [him]74-james astonished [him]74-james ; but it enchanted [him]74-james . [He]74-james was discovering for the first time the soul of [a girl]248-a girl . If [he]74-james was a little taken aback [he]74-james is to be excused . [Younger men]368-younger men than [he]74-james have been taken aback by that discovery . But [James Ollerenshaw]74-james did not behave as [a younger man]369-a younger man would have behaved . [He]74-james was more like [some one who , having heard tell of the rose for sixty years , and having paid no attention to rumour]370-some one who , having heard tell of the rose for sixty years , and having paid no attention to rumour , suddenly sees a rose in early bloom . At [his]74-james age one knows how to treat a flower ; [one]371-one knows what flowers are for .

It was no doubt this knowledge of what flowers are for that almost led to the spilling of milk at the very moment when milk - spilling seemed in a high degree improbable .

The conversation had left [Susan]78-susan and [her]78-susan caprices , and had reached [Helen]79-helen and [her]79-helen solid wisdom .

" But [you]79-helen have n't told [me]372-the old man what [you]79-helen 're doing [i]372-the old man ' [Bosley]18-bosley , "[372-the old man] said [the old man]372-the old man .

" Sew ! "[79-helen] [she]79-helen exclaimed . " [I]79-helen 've given lessons in sewing for years . And cookery . And mathematics . [I]79-helen used to give evening lessons in mathematics at [Longshaw secondary school]1802-longshaw secondary school . "[79-helen]

Great - stepuncle [James]74-james gazed at [her]79-helen . It was useless for [him]74-james to try to pretend to [himself]74-james that [he]74-james was not , secretly , struck all of a heap by the wonders of the living organism in front of [him]74-james . [He]74-james was . And this shows , though [he]74-james was [a wise man]376-a wise man and [an experienced]377-an experienced , how ignorant [he]74-james was of [the world]220-the world . But [I]0-i do not think [he]74-james was more ignorant of [the world]220-the world than [most wise and experienced men]380-most wise and experienced men are . [He]74-james conceived [Helen Rathbone]79-helen as [an extraordinary , an amazing creature]381-an extraordinary , an amazing creature . [Nothing of the kind]382-nothing of the kind . There are simply thousands of [agreeable and good girls]383-agreeable and good girls who can accomplish herring - bone , omelettes , and simultaneous equations in a breath , as it were . [They]384-they are all over [the kingdom]385-the kingdom , and may be seen in [the streets]386-the streets and [lanes thereof]387-lanes thereof about half - past eight in the morning and again about five o'clock in the evening . But the fact is not generally known . Only [the stern and blasé members of School Boards]388-the stern and blasé members of school boards or [Education Committees]19-education committees know it . And [they]384-they are so used to marvels that [they]384-they make nothing of [them]384-they .

However , [James Ollerenshaw]74-james had no intention of striking [his]74-james flag .

Consols happened to be at eighty - nine that day .

[He]74-james had struck [his]74-james flag .

It is painful to be compelled to reinforce the old masculine statement that [women]329-women have no sense of honour . But have [they]329-women ? " Two pounds and one half - penny - to the nearest farthing , "[79-helen] said [she]79-helen , a faint blush crimsoning [her]79-helen cheek .

" [You]79-helen must be same as [[them]1810-they hospital nurses]1811-them hospital nurses , "[74-james] [he]74-james said , aloud . " [You]79-helen do it because [ye]79-helen like it - for love on it , as [they]1810-they say . "[74-james]

"[79-helen]

" Seventy pounds a year on [ye]399-he clothes ! [Ye're]399-he not serious , [lass]1738-lass ? "[79-helen]

[She]79-helen looked at [him]399-he coldly . " [I]79-helen am serious , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said .

Experienced as [he]399-he was , [he]399-he had never come across a fact so incredible as this fact . And the compulsion of believing it occupied [his]399-he forces to such an extent that [he]399-he had no force left to be wise . [He]399-he did not observe the icy , darting challenge in [her]79-helen eye , and [he]399-he ignored the danger in [her]79-helen voice .

" All as [I]399-he can say is [you]79-helen ought to be ashamed o ' [yourself]79-helen , [lass]1738-lass ! "[399-he] [he]399-he said , sharply . Now , [James Ollerenshaw]74-james was not [the first person whom [Helen]79-helen 's passion for clothes had driven into indiscretions]400-the first person whom helen 's passion for clothes had driven into indiscretions . [[Her]79-helen mother]332-her mother , for example , had done battle with that passion , and had been defeated with heavy loss . [A headmistress]402-a headmistress and [a chairman of [a School Board]404-a school board]403-a chairman of a school board [a pompous coward]405-a pompous coward had also suffered severely . [Her]79-helen campaigns and conquests had left [her]79-helen , on this matter , " touchy "[79-helen] - as the word is used in [the Five Towns]193-the five towns .

" [I]332-her mother shall be very much obliged if [you]399-he will not speak to [me]332-her mother in that tone , "[332-her mother] said [she]332-her mother . The milk was within the twentieth of an inch of the brim . [James Ollerenshaw]74-james blushed as red as [Helen]79-helen [herself]79-helen had blushed at the beginning of [their]408-their acquaintance . [A girl]248-a girl , [the daughter of the chit [Susan]78-susan]410-the daughter of the chit susan , to address [him]74-james so ! [She]248-a girl had the incomparable insolence of [[her]248-a girl mother]332-her mother . Yes , thirty years ago [Susan]78-susan had been just as rude to [him]74-james . But [he]74-james was thirty years younger then ; [he]74-james was not [a sage of sixty then]412-a sage of sixty then . [He]74-james continued to blush . [He]74-james was raging . Indeed , it would be no exaggeration to assert that [his]74-james health was momentarily in peril . [He]74-james glanced for an instant at [Helen]79-helen , and saw that [her]79-helen nostrils were twitching . Then [he]74-james looked hurriedly away , and rose . [The captain of [the bowling club]414-the bowling club]413-the captain of the bowling club excusably assumed that [James]74-james was at length going to attack the serious business of the day .

" Now , [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james ! "[415-the captain] [the captain]415-the captain called out ; and [his]415-the captain tone implied , gently : " Do n't [you]74-james think [you]74-james 've kept [me]415-the captain waiting long enough ? [Women]329-women are [women]329-women ; but a bowling - match is a bowling - match . "[415-the captain]

[James]74-james turned [his]74-james back on [the captain]415-the captain , moved off , and then - how can one explain it ? [He]74-james realised that in the last six words of [Helen]79-helen 's speech there had been a note , a hint , a mere nothing , of softness , of regret for pain caused . [He]74-james realised , further , the great universal natural law that under any circumstances - no matter what [they]417-they may be - when [any man]418-any man - no matter who [he]418-any man may be - differs from [any pretty and well - dressed woman]419-any pretty and well - dressed woman - no matter who [she]419-any pretty and well - dressed woman may be - [he]418-any man is in the wrong . [He]74-james saw that it was useless for [serious , logical , high - minded persons]420-serious , logical , high - minded persons to inveigh against the absurdity of this law , and to call it bad names . The law of gravity is absurd and indefensible when [you]421-you fall [downstairs]422-downstairs ; but [you]421-you obey it .

[He]74-james returned to [Helen]79-helen , who bravely met [his]74-james eyes . " [I]74-james 'm off [home]1773-home , "[74-james] [he]74-james said , hoarsely . " It 's [my]74-james tea - time . "[74-james]

" Good - afternoon , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen replied , with amiability .

" Happen [you]74-james 'll come along with [me]74-james , like ? "[74-james]

The use of that word " like "[79-helen] at the end of an interrogative sentence , in [the Five Towns]193-the five towns , is a subject upon which a book ought to be written ; but not this history . The essential point to observe is that [Helen]79-helen got up from the bench and said , with adorable sweetness :

" Why , [I]79-helen shall be charmed to come ! "[79-helen]

" What aperfect old darling [he]74-james is ! "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said to [herself]79-helen .

Contents Chapter 5

A SALUTATION

As [they]424-they walked down [Moorthorne -]20-moorthorne - road towards [the town]224-the town [they]424-they certainly made a couple piquant enough , by reason of the excessive violence of the contrast between [them]424-they , to amuse the eye of [the beholder]426-the beholder . [A young and pretty woman who spends seventy pounds a year on [her]79-helen ornamentations , walking by the side of [a little old man]428-a little old man [she]79-helen had the better of [him]428-a little old man]427-a young and pretty woman who spends seventy pounds a year on her ornamentations , walking by the side of a little old man she had the better of him by [an inch who had probably not spent seventy pounds on clothes in sixty years]429-an inch who had probably not spent seventy pounds on clothes in sixty years - such a spectacle must have drawn attention even in the least attentive of [towns]430-towns . And [Bursley]1-bursley is far from the least attentive of [towns]430-towns . [James]74-james and [[his]74-james great - stepniece]432-his great - stepniece had not got as far as [the new Independent Chapel]433-the new independent chapel when it was known in [St. Luke's - square]21-st. luke's - square , a long way farther on , that [they]424-they were together ; [a tramcar]434-a tramcar had flown forward with the interesting fact . From that moment , of course , the news , which really was great news , spread itself over [the town]224-the town with the rapidity of a perfume ; [no corner]436-no corner could escape it . [All [James]74-james 's innumerable [tenants]438-tenants]437-all james 's innumerable tenants seemed to sniff it simultaneously . And that evening in [the mouth of [the entire town]440-the entire town]439-the mouth of the entire town [I]0-i am licensing [myself]0-i to a little poetical exaggeration there was no word but the word " [Jimmy]74-james . "[424-they]

[Their]424-they converse , as [they]424-they descended into [the town]224-the town , was not effective . It was , indeed , feeble . [They]424-they had fought a brief but bitter duel , and [James Ollerenshaw]74-james had been severely wounded . [His]74-james dignity bled freely ; [he]74-james made , strange to say , scarcely any attempt to staunch the blood , which might have continued to flow for a considerable time had not a diversion occurred . It is well known that the dignity will only bleed while [you]442-you watch it . Avert [your]442-you eyes , and it instantly dries up . The diversion , apparently of a trifling character , had , in truth , an enormous importance , though [the parties concerned]443-the parties concerned did not perceive this till later . It consisted in the passing of [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter and [[her]84-mrs. prockter stepson]444-her stepson , [Emanuel Prockter]95-emanuel , up [Duck Bank]22-duck bank as [James]74-james and [Helen]79-helen were passing down [Duck Bank]22-duck bank .

[Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter who by reason of the rare " k "[84-mrs. prockter] in [her]84-mrs. prockter name regarded [herself]84-mrs. prockter as [the sole genuine in [a district full of [Proctors]447-proctors]446-a district full of proctors may be described as [the dowager of [Bursley]1-bursley]448-the dowager of bursley , [the custodian of [its]1-bursley respectability , and the summit of [its]1-bursley social ladder]449-the custodian of its respectability , and the summit of its social ladder]445-the sole genuine in a district full of proctors may be described as the dowager of bursley , the custodian of its respectability , and the summit of its social ladder . [You]450-you could not climb higher than [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter . [She]84-mrs. prockter lived at [Hillport]23-hillport , and even in [that haughty suburb]451-that haughty suburb there was [none who dared palter]452-none who dared palter with an invitation from [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter . [She]84-mrs. prockter was stout and deliberate . [She]84-mrs. prockter had waving flowers in [her]84-mrs. prockter bonnet and pictures of flowers on [her]84-mrs. prockter silken gown , and a grey mantle . Much of [her]84-mrs. prockter figure preceded [her]84-mrs. prockter as [she]84-mrs. prockter walked . [[Her]84-mrs. prockter stepson]444-her stepson had a tenor voice and [a good tailor]454-a good tailor ; [his]444-her stepson age was thirty .

Now , [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter was simply nothing to [James Ollerenshaw]74-james . [They]455-they knew [each other]456-each other by sight , but [their]455-they orbits did not touch . [James]74-james would have gone by [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter as indifferently as [he]74-james would have gone by [a policeman]457-a policeman or a lamppost . As for [Emanuel]95-emanuel , [James]74-james held [him]95-emanuel in mild , benignant contempt . But when , as [the two pairs]458-the two pairs approached [one another]311-one another , [James]74-james perceived [Emanuel]95-emanuel furtively shifting [his]95-emanuel gold - headed cane from [his]95-emanuel right hand to [his]95-emanuel left , and then actually raise [his]95-emanuel hat to [Helen]79-helen , [James]74-james swiftly lost [his]74-james indifference . [He]74-james also nearly lost [his]74-james presence of mind . [He]74-james was utterly unaccustomed to such crises . Despite [his]74-james wealthy indifference to [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter , despite [his]74-james distinguished scorn of [Emanuel]95-emanuel , despite the richness of [Helen]79-helen 's attire , [he]74-james was astounded , and deeply impressed , to learn that [Helen]79-helen had the acquaintance of [people like [the Prockters]96-the prockters]460-people like the prockters . Further , except at grave - sides , [James Ollerenshaw]74-james had never in [his]74-james life raised [his]74-james hat . Hat - raising formed no part of [his]74-james code of manners . In [his]74-james soul [he]74-james looked upon hat - raising as affected . [He]74-james believed that [all people who raised hats]461-all people who raised hats did so from a snobbish desire to put on airs . Hat - raising was rather like saying " please , "[74-james] only worse .

Happily , [his]74-james was one of those strong , self - reliant natures that can , when there is no alternative , face the most frightful situations with un - thumping heart . [He]74-james kept [his]74-james presence of mind , and decided in the fraction of a second what [he]74-james must do . The faculty of instant decision is indispensable to safety in these swift - rising crises .

[He]74-james raised [his]74-james hat , praying that [Helen]79-helen would not stop to speak . Not gracefully , not with the beauteous curves of [an Emanuel]95-emanuel did [he]74-james raise [his]74-james hat - but [he]74-james raised it . [His]74-james prayer was answered .

" There ! "[74-james] [his]74-james chest said to [Helen]79-helen . " If [you]79-helen thought [I]74-james did n't know how to behave to [[your]79-helen conceited acquaintances]1828-your conceited acquaintances , [you]79-helen were mistaken . "[74-james]

And [his]74-james casual , roving eye pretended that hat - raising was simply the most ordinary thing on [earth]462-earth .

Such was the disturbing incident which ended the bleeding of [his]74-james dignity . In order to keep up the pretence that hat - raising was a normal function of [his]74-james daily life [he]74-james was obliged to talk freely ; and [he]74-james did talk freely . But neither [he]74-james nor [Helen]79-helen said a word as to [the Prockters]96-the prockters .

[MRS BUTT]97-mrs. butt 'S [DEPARTURE

[James Ollerenshaw]74-james 's house]463-departure james ollerenshaw 's house was within a few hundred yards of [the top of [Trafalgar - road]24-trafalgar - road]464-the top of trafalgar - road , on the way from [Bursley]1-bursley to [Hanbridge]25-hanbridge . [I]0-i may not indicate [the exact house]465-the exact house , but [I]0-i can scarcely conceal that [it]465-the exact house lay between [Nos . 160 and 180]466-nos . 160 and 180 , on the left as [you]467-you go up . [It]465-the exact house was [one of [the oldest houses in [the street]1771-the street]469-the oldest houses in the street]468-one of the oldest houses in the street , and though bullied into insignificance by [sundry detached and semi - detached villas]471-sundry detached and semi - detached villas opposite - palaces occupied by [reckless persons who think nothing of paying sixty or even sixty - five pounds a year for rent alone]472-reckless persons who think nothing of paying sixty or even sixty - five pounds a year for rent alone - [it]465-the exact house kept a certain individuality and distinction because [it]465-the exact house had been conscientiously built of good brick before English domestic architecture had lost trace of the Georgian style . First [you]467-you went up two white steps white in theory , through a little gate in a wrought - iron railing painted the colour of peas after they have been cooked in [a bad restaurant]473-a bad restaurant . [You]467-you then found [yourself]467-you in [a little front yard]474-a little front yard , twelve feet in width the whole width of [the house]475-the house by six feet in depth . [The yard]476-the yard was paved with large square Indian - red tiles , except a tiny circle in the midst bordered with black - currant - coloured tiles set endwise with a scolloped edge . This magical circle contained earth , and in the centre of [it]475-the house was a rhododendron bush which , having fallen into lazy habits , had forgotten the art of flowering . Its leaves were a most pessimistic version of the tint of the railing .

The façade of [the house]475-the house comprised three windows and a door - that is to say , a window and a door on the ground floor and two windows above . The brickwork was assuredly admirable ; [James]74-james had it " pointed "[74-james] every few years . Over the windows the bricks , of special shapes , were arranged as in a flat arch , with a keystone that jutted slightly . The panes of the windows were numerous and small ; inside , on the sashes , lay long thin scarlet sausages of red cloth and sawdust , to keep out the draughts . The door was divided into eight small panels with elaborate beadings , and over it was a delicate fanlight - one of about a score in [Bursley]1-bursley - to remind [the observer]478-the observer of a lost elegance . Between the fanlight and the upstairs window exactly above [it]475-the house was a rusty iron plaque , with vestiges in gilt of the word " Phonix . "[478-the observer] It had been put there when fire insurance had still the fancied charm of novelty . At the extremity of the façade farthest from the door a spout came down from the blue slate roof . [This spout]479-this spout began with a bold curve from the projecting horizontal spout under the eaves , and made another curve at the ground into a hollow earthenware grid with very tiny holes .

[Helen]79-helen looked delicious in [the yard]476-the yard , gazing pensively at the slothful rhododendron while [James Ollerenshaw]74-james opened [his]74-james door . [She]79-helen was seen by [two electric cars]481-two electric cars - full of [people]304-people , for although [James]74-james 's latchkey was very highly polished and the lock well oiled , [he]74-james never succeeded in opening [his]74-james door at the first attempt . It was a capricious door . [You]483-you could not be sure of opening [it]475-the house any more than [Beau Brummel]98-beau brummel could be sure of tying [his]98-beau brummel cravat . It was a muse that had to be wooed .

But when it did open [you]483-you perceived that there were no half measures about that door , for it let [you]483-you straight into [the house]475-the house . To open it was like taking down part of the wall . [No lobby]485-no lobby , [hall]486-hall , or vestibule behind that door ! One instant [you]483-you were in [the yard]476-the yard , the next [you]483-you were in the middle of [the sitting - room]488-the sitting - room , and through a doorway at the back of [the sitting - room]488-the sitting - room [you]483-you could see [the kitchen]490-the kitchen , and beyond that [the scullery]491-the scullery , and beyond that [a back yard]492-a back yard with a whitewashed wall .

[James Ollerenshaw]74-james went in first , leaving [Helen]79-helen to follow . [He]74-james had learnt much in the previous hour , but there were still one or two odd things left for [him]74-james to learn .

" Ah ! "[74-james] [he]74-james breathed , shut the door , and hung up [his]74-james hard hat on the inner face of it . " Sit [ye]79-helen down , [lass]1738-lass . "[74-james]

So [she]79-helen sat [her]79-helen down . It must be said that [she]79-helen looked as it [she]79-helen had made a mistake and got on to [the wrong side of [Trafalgar - road]24-trafalgar - road]493-the wrong side of trafalgar - road . [The sitting - room]488-the sitting - room was [a crowded and shabby little apartment]495-a crowded and shabby little apartment though clean . There was a list carpet over the middle of the floor , which was tiled , and in the middle of the carpet a small square table with flap - sides . On this table was a full - rigged ship on [a stormy sea]496-a stormy sea in a glass box , some resin , a large stone bottle of ink , a ready reckoner , [Whitaker]99-whitaker 's Almanack paper edition , a foot - rule , and a bright brass candlestick . Above the table there hung from the ceiling a string with a ball of fringed paper , designed for the amusement of flies . At the window was a flat desk , on which were transacted the affairs of [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james . When [he]74-james stationed [himself]74-james at [it]497-it in the seat of custom and of judgment , defaulting [tenants]438-tenants , twirling caps or twisting aprons , had a fine view of the left side of [his]74-james face . [He]74-james usually talked to [them]438-tenants while staring out of the window . Before this desk was a Windsor chair . There were eight other Windsor chairs in [the room]499-the room - [Helen]79-helen was sitting on one that had not been sat upon for years and years - a teeming but idle population of chairs . A horsehair arm - chair seemed to be the sultan of the seraglio of chairs . Opposite the window a modern sideboard , which might have cost two - nineteen - six when new , completed the tale of furniture . The general impression was one of fulness ; the low ceiling , and the immense harvest of overblown blue roses which climbed luxuriantly up the walls , intensified this effect . The mantelpiece was crammed with brass ornaments , and there were two complete sets of brass fire - irons in the brass fender . Above the mantelpiece a looking - glass , in a wan frame of bird's - eye maple , with rounded corners , reflected [Helen]79-helen 's hat .

[Helen]79-helen abandoned the Windsor chair and tried the arm - chair , and then stood up .

" Which chair do [you]74-james recommend ? "[79-helen] [she]79-helen asked , nicely .

" Bless [ye]74-james , [child]1830-child ! [I]79-helen never sit [here]1785-here , except at th ' desk . [I]79-helen sit in [the kitchen]490-the kitchen . "[79-helen]

A peculiarity of [houses in [the Five Towns]193-the five towns]500-houses in the five towns is that [rooms]502-rooms are seldom called by [their]502-rooms right names . It is a point of honour , among [the self - respecting and industrious classes]503-the self - respecting and industrious classes , to prepare [a room]504-a room elaborately for a certain purpose , and then not to use [it]504-a room for that purpose . Thus [[James Ollerenshaw]74-james 's sitting - room]505-james ollerenshaw 's sitting - room , though surely [few apartments]506-few apartments could show more facilities than [it]505-james ollerenshaw 's sitting - room showed for sitting , was not used as [a sitting - room]507-a sitting - room , but as [an office]508-an office . [The kitchen]490-the kitchen , though [it]490-the kitchen contained [a range]510-a range , was not used as [a kitchen]511-a kitchen , but as [a sitting - room]507-a sitting - room . [The scullery]491-the scullery , though [it]491-the scullery had no range , was filled with a gas cooking - stove and used as [a kitchen]511-a kitchen . And [the back yard]515-the back yard was used as [a scullery]516-a scullery . This arrangement never struck [anybody]517-anybody as singular ; it did not strike even [Helen]79-helen as singular . [[[Her]79-helen mother]332-her mother 's house]519-her mother 's house had exhibited the same oddness until [she]79-helen reorganised [it]519-her mother 's house . If [James Ollerenshaw]74-james had not needed [an office]508-an office , [[his]74-james sitting - room]521-his sitting - room would have languished in desuetude . The fact is that [the thrifty inhabitants of [the Five Towns]193-the five towns]522-the thrifty inhabitants of the five towns save [a room]504-a room as [they]522-the thrifty inhabitants of the five towns save money . If [they]522-the thrifty inhabitants of the five towns have an income of [six rooms]525-six rooms [they]522-the thrifty inhabitants of the five towns will live on five , or rather in five , and thereby take pride to [themselves]522-the thrifty inhabitants of the five towns .

" [I]79-helen suppose [you]74-james have [a good servant]1833-a good servant ? "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said .

[He]74-james preceded [her]79-helen into [the kitchen]490-the kitchen . The door between [the kitchen]490-the kitchen and [the scullery]491-the scullery was half - closed ; in the aperture [he]74-james again had a momentary , but distinct , glimpse of the eye of [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt .

" [I]79-helen do like [this room]1845-this room , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen , enthusiastically .

" Uninterrupted view o ' [th ' back yard]1846-th ' back yard , "[74-james] said [Ollerenshaw]74-james . " Sit [ye]79-helen down , [lass]1738-lass . "[74-james]

[He]74-james indicated an article of furniture which stood in front of [the range]531-the range , at a distance of perhaps six feet from [it]531-the range , cutting [the room]499-the room in half . This contrivance may be called a sofa , or it may be called a couch ; but it can only be properly described by the Midland word for it - squab . No other term is sufficiently expressive . [Its]531-the range seat - five feet by two - was very broad and very low , and [it]531-the range had a steep , high back and sides . All its angles were right angles . It was everywhere comfortably padded ; it yielded everywhere to firm pressure ; and it was covered with a grey and green striped stuff . [You]533-you could not sit on that squab and be in a draught ; yet behind it , lest the impossible should arrive , was a heavy curtain , hung on an iron rod which crossed [the room]499-the room from wall to wall . Not much imagination was needed to realise the joy and ecstasy of losing [yourself]533-you on that squab on a winter afternoon , with the range fire roaring in [your]533-you face , and the curtain drawn abaft .

[Helen]79-helen assumed the mathematical centre of the squab , and began to arrange [her]79-helen skirts in cascading folds ; [she]79-helen had posed [her]79-helen parasol in a corner of it , as though the squab had been [a railway carriage]535-a railway carriage , which , indeed , [it]531-the range did somewhat resemble .

[He]372-the old man took it , as though it had been of glass , and hung it on the nail .

Without [her]79-helen hat [she]79-helen looked as if [she]79-helen lived [there]252-there , a jewel in a pipe - case . [She]79-helen appeared to be just as much at [home]1773-home as [he]372-the old man was . And [they]542-they were so at [home]1773-home together that there was no further necessity to strain after a continuous conversation . " So [you]372-the old man have all [your]372-the old man meals here ? "[79-helen] [she]79-helen ventured .

" [I]372-the old man have what [I]372-the old man 'm given , "[372-the old man] [he]372-the old man replied . " [I]372-the old man fancy a snack for [my]372-the old man tea . Something tasty , [ye]79-helen know . "[372-the old man]

" Why , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said , " [you]372-the old man 're just like [me]79-helen . [I]79-helen adore tea . [I]79-helen 'd sooner have tea than any other meal of the day .
