"[79-helen]

" So - so ! "[74-james] [James]74-james murmured .

" The trouble with [servants]1853-servants is that [they]1853-servants always think that if [you]372-the old man like a thing one day [you]372-the old man 'll like the same thing every day for the next three years . "[79-helen]

" Ay , "[372-the old man] [he]372-the old man said , drily . " [I]372-the old man used to like a kidney , but it 's more than three years ago . "[372-the old man] [He]372-the old man stuck [his]372-the old man lips out , and raised [himself]372-the old man higher than ever on [his]372-the old man toes .

[He]372-the old man did not laugh . But [she]548-she laughed , almost boisterously .

" [I]548-she ca n't help telling [you]372-the old man , "[548-she] [she]548-she said , " [you]372-the old man 're perfectly lovely , [great - stepuncle]1824-great - stepuncle . Are [we]1856-we both going to drink out of the same cup ? "[548-she] In such manner did the current of [her]548-she talk gyrate and turn corners .

[He]372-the old man approached the cupboard .

" No , no ! "[548-she] [She]548-she sprang up . " Let [me]548-she . [I]548-she 'll do that , as [the servant]1857-the servant is so long . "[548-she]

And [she]548-she opened the cupboard . Among a miscellany of crocks therein was a blue - and - white cup and saucer , and a plate to match underneath it , that seemed out of place there . [She]548-she lifted down the pile .

" Steady on ! "[372-the old man] [he]372-the old man counselled [her]548-she . " Why dun [you]548-she choose that ? "[372-the old man]

" Because [I]548-she like it , "[548-she] [she]548-she replied , simply .

[He]372-the old man was silenced . " That 's a bit o ' real Spode , "[372-the old man] [he]372-the old man said , as [she]548-she put it on the table and dusted the several pieces with a corner of the tablecloth .

" It wo n't be in any danger , "[548-she] [she]548-she retorted , " until it comes to be washed up . So [I]548-she 'll stop afterwards and wash it up [myself]548-she . There ! "[548-she]

" Now [you]548-she ca n't find the teaspoons , [miss]1793-miss ! "[372-the old man] [he]372-the old man challenged [her]548-she .

" [I]548-she think [I]548-she can , "[548-she] [she]548-she said .

[She]548-she raised the tablecloth at the end , discovered the knob of a drawer , and opened it . And , surely , there were teaspoons .

" Ca n't [I]548-she just take a peep into [the scullery]491-the scullery ? "[548-she] [she]548-she begged , with a bewitching supplication . " [I]548-she wo n't stop . It 's nearly time [[your]74-james servant]1851-your servant was back , if [she]1851-your servant 's always so dreadfully prompt as [you]74-james say . [I]548-she wo n't touch anything . [Servants]1853-servants are so silly . [They]1853-servants always think [one]371-one wants to interfere with [them]1853-servants . "[548-she]

Without waiting for [James]74-james 's permission , [she]548-she burst youthfully into [the scullery]491-the scullery .

" Oh , "[548-she] [she]548-she exclaimed , " there 's [some one]1863-some one [here]1785-here ! "[548-she]

Of course there was . There was [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt .

Although the part played by [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt in the drama was vehement and momentous , it was nevertheless so brief that a description of [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt is hardly called for . Suffice it to say that [she]97-mrs. butt had so much waist as to have no waist , and that [she]97-mrs. butt possessed both a beard and a moustache . This curt catalogue of [her]97-mrs. butt charms is unfair to [her]97-mrs. butt ; but [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt was ever the victim of unfairness .

[James Ollerenshaw]74-james looked audaciously in at the door . " It 's [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt , "[74-james] said [he]74-james . " [Us]1865-us thought as [ye]97-mrs. butt were out . "[74-james]

" Good - afternoon , [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt , "[79-helen] [Helen]79-helen began , with candid pleasantness .

A pause .

" Good - afternoon , [miss]1793-miss . "[97-mrs. butt]

" And what have [you]97-mrs. butt got for [uncle]1867-uncle 's tea to - day ? Something tasty ? "[97-mrs. butt]

Contents Chapter 7

[THE NEW COOK]551-the new cook

Ten minutes later [Mr. James Ollerenshaw]74-james stood alone in [[his]74-james kitchen - sitting - room]552-his kitchen - sitting - room . And [he]74-james gazed at the door between the [kitchen - sitting - room]553-kitchen - sitting - room and [the scullery]491-the scullery . This door was shut ; that is to say , [it]555-it was nearly shut . [He]74-james had been turned out of [the scullery]491-the scullery ; not with violence - or , rather , with a sort of sweet violence that [he]74-james liked , and that had never before been administered to [him]74-james by [any human soul]557-any human soul . An afternoon highly adventurous - an afternoon on which [he]74-james had permitted [himself]74-james to be insulted , with worse than impunity to [the insulter]558-the insulter , by [the childish daughter of that chit Susan]559-the childish daughter of that chit susan - an afternoon on which [he]74-james had raised [his]74-james hat to [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter - a Saturday afternoon on which [he]74-james had foregone , on account of [a woman]231-a woman , [his]74-james customary match at bowls - this afternoon was drawing to a close in a manner which piled thrilling event on thrilling event .

[Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt had departed . For unnumbered years [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt had miscooked [his]74-james meals . [The little house]561-the little house was almost inconceivable without [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt . And [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt had departed . Already [he]74-james missed [her]97-mrs. butt as one misses [an ancient and supersensitive corn]562-an ancient and supersensitive corn - if the simile may be permitted to one ; it is a simile not quite nice , but , then , [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt was not quite nice either . The fault was not [hers]97-mrs. butt ; [she]97-mrs. butt was born so .

The dropping of the kidney with a plop , by [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt , on [the hard , unsympathetic floor of [the scullery]491-the scullery]563-the hard , unsympathetic floor of the scullery , had constituted an extremely dramatic moment in three lives . Certainly [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt possessed a wondrous instinct for theatrical effect . [Helen]79-helen , on the contrary , seemed to possess none . [She]79-helen had advanced nonchalantly towards the kidney , and delicately picked it up between finger and thumb , and turned it over , and then put it on a plate .

" That 's a veal kidney , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen had observed .

" Art sure it is n't a sheep 's kidney , [lass]1738-lass ? "[74-james] [James]74-james had asked , carefully imitating [Helen]79-helen 's nonchalance .

" Yes , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen had said . " [I]79-helen gather [you]1738-lass are not passionately fond of kidneys , [great - stepuncle?'she]1879-great - stepuncle?'she had asked .[79-helen]

" [I]79-helen was once . What art going to do , [lass]1738-lass ? "[79-helen]

" [I]79-helen 'm going to get [our]565-our tea , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen had said .

At the words , [our]565-our tea , the antique [James Ollerenshaw , who had never]74-james [thought to have such a sensation]566-thought to have such a sensation again , was most distinctly conscious of an agreeable , somewhat disturbing sensation of being tickled in the small of [his]74-james back .

" Well , "[74-james] [he]74-james had asked [her]79-helen , " what can [I]74-james do ? "[74-james]

" [You]74-james can go out , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen had replied . " Would n't it be a good thing for [you]74-james to go out for a walk ? Tea will be ready at half - past four . "[79-helen]

" [I]74-james go for no walk , "[74-james] [he]74-james said , positively .

" Yes , that 's all right , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen had murmured , but not in response to [his]74-james flat refusal to obey [her]79-helen . [She]79-helen had been opening the double cupboard and the five drawers which constituted the receptacles of the scullery - larders ; [she]79-helen had been spying out the riches and the poverty of [the establishment]567-the establishment . Then [she]79-helen had turned to [him]74-james , and , instead of engaging [him]74-james in battle , [she]79-helen had just smiled at [him]74-james , and said : " Very well . As [you]74-james wish . But do go into [the front room]1881-the front room , at any rate . "[79-helen]

And there [he]74-james was in [the middle room]568-the middle room , [the kitchen]490-the kitchen , listening to [her]79-helen movements behind the door . [He]74-james heard the running of water , and then the mild explosion of lighting the second ring of the gas - stove ; the first had been lighted by [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt . Then [he]74-james heard nothing whatever for years , and when [he]74-james looked at the clock it was fourteen minutes past four . In the act of looking at the clock , [his]74-james eye had to traverse the region of the sofa . On the sofa were one parasol and two gloves . Astonishing , singuIar , disconcerting , how those articles - which , after all , bore no kind of resemblance to any style of furniture or hangings - seemed , nevertheless , to refurnish [the room]499-the room , to give [the room]499-the room an air of being thickly inhabited which [it]499-the room never had before !

Then [she]79-helen burst into [the kitchen]490-the kitchen unexpectedly , with a swish of silk that was like the retreat of waves down the shingle of [some Atlantic shore]573-some atlantic shore .

" [[My]79-helen dear uncle]1882-my dear uncle , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen protested , " please do make [yourself]74-james scarce . [You]74-james are in [my]79-helen way , and [I]79-helen 'm very busy . "[79-helen]

[She]79-helen went to the cupboard and snatched at some plates , two of which [she]79-helen dropped on the table , and three of which [she]79-helen took into [the kitchen]490-the kitchen .

" Have [ye]79-helen got all as [ye]79-helen want ? "[74-james] [he]74-james questioned [her]79-helen politely , anxious to be of assistance .

" Everything ! "[79-helen] [she]79-helen answered , positively , and with just the least hint of an intention to crush [him]74-james .

" Have [ye]74-james indeed ! "[79-helen]

[He]74-james did not utter this exclamation aloud ; but with it [he]74-james applied balm to [his]74-james secret breast , For [he]74-james still remembered , being [an old man]348-an old man , [her]79-helen crushing [him]74-james in [the park]188-the park , and the peril of another crushing roused [the male in [him]74-james]577-the male in him . And it was with a sardonic and cruel satisfaction that [he]74-james applied such balm to [his]74-james secret breast . The truth was , [he]74-james knew that [she]79-helen had not got all [she]79-helen wanted . [He]74-james knew that , despite [her]79-helen extraordinary capableness of which [she]79-helen was rather vain , despite [her]79-helen ability to calculate mentally the interest on eighty - nine pounds for six months at four - and - a - half per cent . , [she]79-helen could not possibly prepare the tea without coming to [him]74-james and confessing to [him]74-james that [she]79-helen had been mistaken , and that [she]79-helen had not got everything [she]79-helen wanted . [She]79-helen would be compelled to humble [herself]79-helen before [him]74-james - were it ever so little . [He]74-james was [a hard old man]578-a hard old man , and the prospect of this humbling gave [him]74-james pleasure [I]0-i regret to say .

[You]579-you can not have tea without tea - leaves ; and [James Ollerenshaw]74-james kept the tea - leaves in a tea - caddy , locked , in [[his]74-james front room]580-his front room . [He]74-james had an extravagant taste in tea . [He]74-james fancied China tea ; and [he]74-james fancied China tea that cost five shillings a pound . [He]74-james was [the last person]581-the last person to leave China tea at five shillings a pound to the economic prudence of [a Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt . Every day [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt brought to [him]74-james the teapot warmed and a teaspoon , and [he]74-james unlocked the tea - caddy , dispensed the right quantity of tea , and relocked the tea - caddy .

There was no other tea in [the house]475-the house . So with a merry heart [the callous fellow]583-the callous fellow shamefully delighting in the imminent downfall of [a fellow - creature]584-a fellow - creature - and that [a woman]231-a woman ! went into [the front room]1881-the front room as [he]74-james had been bidden . On one of the family of chairs , in a corner , was a black octagonal case . [He]74-james opened this case , which was not locked , and drew from it a concertina , all inlaid with mother - of - pearl . Then [he]74-james went to the desk , and from under a pile of rent books [he]74-james extracted several pieces of music , and selected one . This selected piece [he]74-james reared up on the mantelpiece against two brass candlesticks . It was obvious , from the certainty and ease of [his]74-james movements , that [he]74-james had the habit of lodging pieces of music against those two brass candlesticks . The music bore the illustrious name of [George Frederick Handel]102-george frederick handel .

Then [he]74-james put on a pair of spectacles which were lying on the mantelpiece , and balanced them on the end of [his]74-james nose . Finally [he]74-james adjusted [his]74-james little hands to the straps of the concertina . [You]587-you might imagine that be would instantly dissolve into melody . Not at all . [He]74-james glanced at the page of music first through [his]74-james spectacles , and then , bending forward [his]74-james head , over [his]74-james spectacles . Then [he]74-james put down the concertina , gingerly , on a chair , and moved the music half - an - inch perhaps five - eighths to the left . [He]74-james resumed the concertina , and was on the very point of song , when [he]74-james put down the concertina for the second time , and moved the tassel of [his]74-james Turkish cap from the neighbourhood of [his]74-james left ear to the neighbourhood of [his]74-james right ear . Then , with a cough , [he]74-james resumed the concertina once more , and embarked upon the interpretation of [Handel]102-george frederick handel .

It was the Hallelujah Chorus .

Any surprise which [the musical reader]588-the musical reader may feel on hearing that [James Ollerenshaw]74-james was equal to performing the Hallelujah Chorus on a concertina even [one inlaid with mother - of - pearl]589-one inlaid with mother - of - pearl argues on the part of [that reader]590-that reader an imperfect acquaintance with [the Five Towns]193-the five towns . In [the Five Towns]193-the five towns there are among piano scorners two musical instruments , [the concertina and the cornet]593-the concertina and the cornet . And [the Five Towns]193-the five towns would like to see [the composer]595-the composer clever enough to compose a piece of music that can not be arranged for either of these instruments . It is conceivable that [Beethoven]103-beethoven imagined , when [he]103-beethoven wrote the last movement of the C Minor Symphony , that [he]103-beethoven had produced a work which it would be impossible to arrange for cornet solo . But if [he]103-beethoven did [he]103-beethoven imagined a vain thing . In [the Five Towns]193-the five towns , where the taste for classical music is highly developed , the C Minor Symphony on a single cornet is as common as " Robin Adair "[597-a full brass band] on [a full brass band]597-a full brass band .

[James Ollerenshaw]74-james played the Hallelujah Chorus with much feeling and expression . [He]74-james . understood the Hallelujah Chorus to its profoundest depths ; which was not surprising in view of the fact that [he]74-james had been playing it regularly since before [Helen]79-helen was born . The unfading charm of classical music is , that [you]598-you never tire of it .

Nevertheless , the grandeur of [his]74-james interpretation of the Hallelujah Chorus appeared to produce no effect whatever in [the scullery]491-the scullery ; neither alarm nor ecstasy ! And presently , in the midst of a brief pianissimo passage , [James]74-james 's sensitive ear caught the distant sound of chopping , which quite marred the soft tenderness at which [he]74-james had been aiming . [He]74-james stopped abruptly . The sound of chopping intrigued [his]74-james curiosity . What could [she]600-she be chopping ? [He]74-james advanced cautiously to the doorway ; [he]74-james had left the door open . The other door - between [the kitchen]490-the kitchen and [the scullery]491-the scullery - which had previously been closed , was now open , so that [he]74-james could see from [the front room]1881-the front room into [the scullery]491-the scullery . [His]74-james eager , inquisitive glance noted a plate of beautiful bread and butter on the tea - table in [the kitchen]490-the kitchen .

[She]600-she was chopping the kidney . Utterly absorbed in [her]600-she task , [she]600-she had no suspicion that [she]600-she was being overlooked . After the chopping of the kidney , [James]74-james witnessed a series of operations the key to whose significance [he]74-james could not find .

[She]600-she put a flat pan over the gas , and then took it off again . Then [she]600-she picked up an egg , broke it into a coffee - cup , and instantly poured it out of the coffee - cup into a basin . [She]600-she did the same to another egg , and yet another . Four eggs ! The entire household stock of eggs ! It was terrible ! Four eggs and a kidney among [two people]606-two people ! [He]74-james could not divine what [she]600-she was at .

Then [she]600-she got some butter on the end of a knife and dropped it into the saucepan , and put the saucepan over the gas ; and then poured the plateful of kidney - shreds into the saucepan . Then [she]600-she began furiously to beat the four eggs with a fork , glancing into the saucepan frequently , and coaxing it with little touches . Then the kidney - shreds raised a sound of frizzling , and bang into the saucepan went the contents of the basin . All the time [she]600-she had held [her]600-she hands and [her]600-she implements and utensils away from [her]600-she as much as possible , doubtless out of consideration for [her]600-she frock ; not an inch of apron was [she]600-she wearing . Now [she]600-she leant over the gas - stove , fork in hand , and made baffling motions inside the saucepan with the fork ; and while doing so [she]600-she stretched forth [her]600-she left hand , obtained some salt , and sprinkled the saucepan therewith . The business seemed to be exquisitely delicate and breathless . [Her]600-she face was sternly set , as though the fate of [continents]607-continents depended on [her]600-she nerve and audacity in this tremendous crisis . But what [she]600-she was doing to the interior of the saucepan [James Ollerenshaw]74-james could not comprehend . [She]600-she stroked it with a long gesture ; [she]600-she tickled it , [she]600-she stroked it in a different direction ; [she]600-she lifted it and folded it on itself .

Anyhow , [he]74-james knew it was not scrambled eggs , because [you]608-you have to stir scrambled eggs without ceasing .

Then [she]600-she stopped and stood quite still , regarding the saucepan .

" [You]74-james 've watched [me]600-she quite long enough , "[600-she] [she]600-she said , without moving [her]600-she head . [She]600-she must have known all the time that [he]74-james was there .

So [he]74-james shuffled away , and glanced out of the window at the stir and traffic of [Trafalgar - road]24-trafalgar - road .

" Tea 's ready , "[600-she] [she]600-she said .

[He]74-james went into [the kitchen]490-the kitchen , smiling , enchanted , but disturbed . [She]600-she had not come to [him]74-james and confessed that [she]600-she could not make tea without tea - leaves . Yet there was the tea - pot steaming and puffing on the table !

Contents Chapter 8

OMELETTE

The mystery lay on a plate in the middle of the table . In colour it resembled scrambled eggs , except that it was tinted a more brownish , or coppery , gold - rather like a first - class Yorkshire pudding . [He]74-james suspected for an instant that it might be a Yorkshire pudding according to the new - fangled recipe of [Board Schools]610-board schools . But four eggs ! No ! [He]74-james was sure that so small a quantity of Yorkshire pudding could not possibly have required four eggs .

[He]74-james picked up the teapot , after [his]74-james manner , and was in the act of pouring , when [she]600-she struck [him]74-james into immobility with a loud cry :

" Milk first ! "[600-she]

[He]74-james understood that [she]600-she had a caprice for pouring the tea on the top of the milk instead of the milk on the top of the tea .

" What difference does it make ? "[74-james] [he]74-james demanded defiantly .

" What ! "[600-she] [she]600-she cried again . " [You]74-james think [yourself]74-james a great authority on China tea , and yet [you]74-james do n't know that milk ought to be poured in first ! Why , it makes quite a different taste ! "[600-she]

How in the name of [Confucius]104-confucius did [she]600-she know that [he]74-james thought [himself]74-james a great authority on China tea ?

" Here ! "[600-she] [she]600-she said . " If [you]74-james do n't mind , [I]600-she 'll pour out the tea . Thank [you]74-james . Help [yourself]74-james to this . "[600-she] [She]600-she pointed to the mystery . " It must be eaten while it 's hot , or it 's worse than useless . "[600-she]

What is it ? " [he]74-james asked , with false calm .[74-james]

" It 's a kidney omelette , "[600-she] [she]600-she replied .

" Omelette ! "[74-james] [he]74-james repeated , rather at a loss . [He]74-james had never tasted an omelette ; [he]74-james had never seen an omelette . Omelettes form no part of the domestic cuisine of [England]5-england . " Omelette ! "[74-james] [he]74-james repeated . How was [he]74-james familiar with the word - the word which conveyed nothing to [his]74-james mind ? Then [he]74-james remembered : " [You]600-she ca n't make an omelette without breaking eggs . "[74-james] Of course [she]600-she had broken eggs . [She]600-she had broken four eggs - [she]600-she had broken the entire household stock of eggs . And [he]74-james had employed that proverb scores , hundreds of times ! It was one of half - a - dozen favourite proverbs which [he]74-james flung at the less sagacious and prudent of [[his]74-james tenants]611-his tenants . And yet it had never occurred to [him]74-james to wonder what an omelette was ! Now [he]74-james knew . At any rate , [he]74-james knew what it looked like ; and [he]74-james was shortly to know what it tasted like .

" Yes , "[600-she] [she]600-she said . " Cut it with a knife . Do n't be frightened of it . [You]74-james 'll eat it ; it wo n't eat [you]74-james . And please give [me]600-she very little . [I]600-she ate a quarter of a pound of chocolates after dinner . "[600-she]

[He]74-james conveyed one - third of the confection to [his]74-james plate , and about a sixth to [hers]600-she .

And [he]74-james tasted - just a morsel , with a dash of kidney in the centre of it , on the end of [his]74-james fork . [He]74-james was not aware of the fact , but that was the decisive moment of [his]74-james life - sixty though [he]74-james was !

Had [she]600-she really made this marvel , this dream , this idyll , this indescribable bliss , out of four common fresh eggs and a veal kidney that [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt had dropped on the floor ? [He]74-james had come to loathe kidney . [He]74-james had almost come to swearing that no manifestation or incarnation of kidney should ever again pass between [his]74-james excellent teeth . And now [he]74-james was ravished , rapt away on the wings of paradisaical ecstasy by a something that consisted of kidney and a few eggs . [This omelette]612-this omelette had all the finer and nobler qualities of Yorkshire pudding and scrambled eggs combined , together with others beyond the ken of [his]74-james greedy fancy . Yes , [he]74-james was [a greedy man]613-a greedy man . [He]74-james knew [he]74-james was greedy . [He]74-james was [a greedy man whose evil passion had providentially been kept in check for over a quarter of a century by the gross unskilfulness , the appalling monotony , of [a Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt]614-a greedy man whose evil passion had providentially been kept in check for over a quarter of a century by the gross unskilfulness , the appalling monotony , of a mrs. butt . Could it be that there existed [women]329-women , light and light - handed creatures , [creatures of originality and resource , who were capable of producing prodigies like this kidney omelette on the spur of the moment]616-creatures of originality and resource , who were capable of producing prodigies like this kidney omelette on the spur of the moment ? Evidently ! [Helen]79-helen existed . And the whole omelette , from the melting of the butter to the final steady glance into the saucepan , had not occupied [her]79-helen more than six minutes - at most . [She]79-helen had tossed it off as [he]74-james might have tossed off a receipt for a week 's rent . And the exquisite thought in [his]74-james mind , the thought of penetrating sweetness , was that whence this delicacy had come , other and even rarer delicacies might have come . All [his]74-james past life seemed to [him]74-james to be a miserable waste of gloomy and joyless years .

" Do [you]74-james like it ? "[79-helen] [she]79-helen inquired .

[He]74-james paused , as though reflecting whether [he]74-james liked it or not . " Ay , "[74-james] [he]74-james said , judicially , " it 's none so bad . [I]74-james could do a bit more o ' that . "[74-james]

" Well , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen urged [him]74-james , " do help [yourself]74-james . Take it all . [I]79-helen sha n't eat any more . "[79-helen]

" Sure ? "[74-james] [he]74-james said , trembling lest [she]79-helen might change [her]79-helen mind .

Then [he]74-james ate the remaining half of the omelette , making five - sixths in all . [He]74-james glanced at [her]79-helen surreptitiously , in [her]79-helen fine dress , on which was not a single splash or stain . [He]74-james might have known that so extraordinary and exotic [a female person]617-a female person would not concoct anything so trite as a Yorkshire pudding or scrambled eggs .

Not till the omelette was an affair of the past so far as [his]74-james plate was concerned did [he]74-james begin to attend to [his]74-james tea - [his]74-james tea which sustained a mystery as curious as , and decidedly more sinister than , the mystery of the omelette .

[He]74-james stared into the cup ; then , to use the Five Towns phrase , [he]74-james supped it up .

There could be no doubt ; it was [his]74-james special China tea . It had a peculiar flavour owing , perhaps , to the precedence given to milk , but it was incontestably [his]74-james guarded and locked tea . How had [she]79-helen got it ?

" Where didst find this tea , [lass]1738-lass ? "[74-james] [he]74-james asked .

" In [the little corner cupboard in [the scullery]491-the scullery]1884-the little corner cupboard in the scullery , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said . " [I]79-helen 'd no idea that [people]304-people drank such good China tea in [Bursley]1-bursley . "[79-helen]

" Ah ! "[74-james] [he]74-james observed , concealing [his]74-james concern under a mask of irony , " China tea was drunk [i]74-james ' [Bursley]1-bursley afore [your]79-helen time . "[74-james]

" [Mother]1743-mother would only drink [Ceylon]105-ceylon , "[79-helen] said [she]79-helen .

" That doesna ' surprise [me]74-james , "[74-james] said [he]74-james , as if to imply that no vagary on the part of [Susan]78-susan could surprise [him]74-james . And [he]74-james proceeded , reflectively : " In [th ' corner cupboard]1888-th ' corner cupboard , sayst tha ? "[74-james]

" Yes , in a large tin box . "[74-james]

A large tin box . This news was overwhelming . [He]74-james rose abruptly and went into [the scullery]491-the scullery . Indubitably there was a large tin box , pretty nearly half full of [his]74-james guarded tea , in the corner cupboard .

[He]74-james returned , the illusion of half a lifetime shattered . " That there [woman]1889-woman was [a thief]1890-a thief ! "[74-james] [he]74-james announced .

" [What woman]1891-what woman ? "[74-james]

" [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt . "[74-james]

And [he]74-james explained to [Helen]79-helen all [his]74-james elaborate precautions for the preservation of [his]74-james China tea1 [Helen]79-helen was wholly sympathetic . The utter correctness of [her]79-helen attitude towards [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt was balm to [him]74-james . Only one theory was conceivable . [The wretched woman]619-the wretched woman must have had a key to [[his]74-james caddy]620-his caddy . During [his]74-james absence from [the house]475-the house [she]619-the wretched woman must have calmly helped [herself]619-the wretched woman to tea at five shillings a pound - a spoonful or so at a time . Doubtless [she]619-the wretched woman made tea for [her]619-the wretched woman private consumption exactly when [she]619-the wretched woman chose . It was even possible that [she]619-the wretched woman walked off from time to time with quantities of tea to [[her]619-the wretched woman own home]622-her own home . And [he]74-james who thought [himself]74-james so clever , so much cleverer than [a servant]623-a servant !

" [You]74-james ca n't have [her]619-the wretched woman back , as [she]619-the wretched woman is n't honest , even if [she]619-the wretched woman comes back , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen .

" Oh , [her]619-the wretched woman wo n't come back , "[74-james] said [James]74-james . " Fact is , [I]74-james 've had difficulties with [her]619-the wretched woman for a long time now . "[74-james]

" Then what shall [you]74-james do , [[my]79-helen poor dear uncle]1892-my poor dear uncle ? "[79-helen]

" Nay , "[74-james] said [he]74-james , " [I]74-james mun ask [you]79-helen that . It was [you]79-helen as was th ' cause of [her]619-the wretched woman going . "[74-james]

" Oh , [uncle]1867-uncle ! "[79-helen] [she]79-helen exclaimed , laughing . " How can [you]1867-uncle say such a thing ? "[79-helen] And [she]79-helen added , seriously : " [You]74-james ca n't be expected to cook for [yourself]74-james , can [you]74-james ? And as for getting a new one - "[79-helen]

[He]74-james noticed with satisfaction that [she]79-helen had taken to calling [him]74-james simply [uncle]1867-uncle , instead of great - stepuncle .

" [A new ' un]1894-a new ' un ! "[74-james] [he]74-james muttered , grimly , and sighed in despair .

" [I]79-helen shall stay and look after [your]74-james supper , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said , brightly .

" Yes , and what about to - morrow ? "[74-james] [He]74-james grew gloomier .

" To - morrow 's Sunday . [I]74-james 'll come to - morrow , for breakfast . "[74-james]

" Yes , and what about Monday ? "[74-james] [His]74-james gloom was not easily to be dispersed .

" [I]79-helen 'll come on Monday , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen replied , with increasing cheerfulness .

" But [[your]79-helen school]1895-your school , where [ye]79-helen teach everything , [lass]1738-lass ? "[74-james]

" Of course , [I]79-helen shall give up school , "[79-helen] said [she]79-helen , " at once . [They]1897-they must do without [me]79-helen . It will mean promotion for some one . [I]79-helen ca n't bother about giving proper notice . Supposing [you]74-james had been dangerously ill , [I]79-helen should have come , and [they]1897-they would have managed without [me]79-helen . Therefore , [they]1897-they can manage without [me]79-helen . Therefore , [they]1897-they must . "[79-helen]

[He]74-james kept up a magnificent gloom until [she]79-helen left for the night . And then [he]74-james danced a hornpipe of glee - not with [his]74-james legs , but in [his]74-james heart . [He]74-james had deliberately schemed to get rid of [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt by means of [Helen Rathbone]79-helen . The idea had occurred to [him]74-james as [he]74-james entered [the house]475-the house . That was why [he]74-james had encouraged [her]79-helen to talk freely about [servants]1853-servants by assuring [her]79-helen that [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt was not in [the scullery]491-the scullery , being well aware that [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt was in [the scullery]491-the scullery . [He]74-james had made a tool of [the unsuspecting , good - natured [Helen]79-helen]629-the unsuspecting , good - natured helen , smart though [she]79-helen was ! [He]74-james had transitory qualms of fear about the possible expensiveness of [Helen]79-helen . [He]74-james had decidedly not meant that [she]79-helen should give up school and nearly thirty shillings a week . But , still , [he]74-james had managed [her]79-helen so far , and [he]74-james reckoned that [he]74-james could continue to manage [her]79-helen .

[He]74-james regretted that [she]79-helen had not praised [his]74-james music . And [Helen]79-helen wrote the same evening to [[her]79-helen mother]332-her mother . From a very long and very exciting letter the following excerpts may be culled :

" [I]79-helen saw [the fat old servant]1898-the fat old servant in [the scullery]491-the scullery at once . But [uncle]1867-uncle thought [she]1898-the fat old servant was n't [there]252-there . [He]1867-uncle is [a funny old man]1902-a funny old man - rather silly , like [most old men]1903-most old men - but [I]79-helen like [him]1867-uncle , and [you]332-her mother can say what [you]332-her mother please . [He]1867-uncle is n't silly really . [I]79-helen instantly decided that [I]79-helen would get rid of [that servant]1904-that servant . And [I]79-helen did do , and [poor uncle]1905-poor uncle never suspected . In a few days [I]79-helen shall come to live [here]1785-here . It 's much safer . Supposing [he]1867-uncle was taken ill and died , and left all [his]1867-uncle money to [hospitals]1907-hospitals and things , how awfully stupid that would be ! [I]79-helen told [him]1867-uncle [I]79-helen should leave [the school]1908-the school , and [he]1867-uncle did n't turn a hair . [He]1867-uncle 's [a dear]1909-a dear , and [I]79-helen do n't care a fig for [his]1867-uncle money - except to spend it for [him]1867-uncle . [[His]1867-uncle tiny house]1910-his tiny house is simply lovely , terrifically clean , and in the loveliest order . But [I]79-helen 've no intention that [we]1911-we shall stay [here]1785-here . [I]79-helen think [I]79-helen shall take [a large house up at [Hillport]23-hillport]1913-a large house up at hillport . [Uncle]1914-uncle is only old in some ways ; in many ways [he]1914-uncle 's quite young . So [I]79-helen hope [he]1914-uncle wo n't mind a change . In such manner came [Helen Rathbone]79-helen to keep [house]631-house for [her]79-helen great - stepuncle .

Contents Chapter 9

A GREAT CHANGE

" [Helen Rathbone]79-helen , "[106-james] said [Uncle James]106-james one Tuesday afternoon , " have [ye]79-helen been meddling in [[my]106-james cashbox]1916-my cashbox ? "[106-james]

[They]632-they were sitting in [the front room]1881-the front room , [Helen]79-helen in a light - grey costume that cascaded over [her]79-helen chair and half the next chair , and [James Ollerenshaw]74-james in the deshabille of [his]74-james Turkish cap . [James]74-james was at [his]74-james desk . It is customary in [the Five Towns]193-the five towns , when [you]635-you feel combative , astonished , or ironic towards [another person]636-another person , to address [that other person]637-that other person by [his]637-that other person full name .

" [You]74-james left the key in [your]74-james cashbox this morning , [uncle]1867-uncle , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen , glancing up from a book , " while [you]74-james were fiddling with [your]74-james safe in [[your]74-james bedroom]1918-your bedroom . "[79-helen]

[He]74-james did not like the word " fiddling . "[74-james] It did not suit either [his]74-james dignity or the dignity of [[his]74-james huge Milner safe]638-his huge milner safe .

" Well , "[74-james] [he]74-james said , " and if [I]74-james did ! [I]74-james was n't [upstairs]1919-upstairs more nor five minutes , and [th ' new servant]1920-th ' new servant had na ' come ! There was but [you]79-helen and [me]74-james in [th ' house]1835-th ' house . "[74-james]

" Yes . But , [you]79-helen see , [I]74-james was in a hurry to go out marketing , and [I]74-james could n't wait for [you]79-helen to come down . "[74-james]

[He]74-james ignored this remark . " There 's a tenpun ' note missing , "[74-james] said [he]74-james . " Do n't play them tricks on [me]74-james , [lass]1738-lass ; [I]74-james 'm getting [an oldish man]1923-an oldish man . Where hast hidden it ? [I]74-james mun go to [th ' bank]1924-th ' bank . "[74-james] [He]74-james spoke plaintively .

" [[My]639-i dear uncle]1882-my dear uncle , "[639-i] [she]639-i replied , " [I]639-i 've not hidden [your]1882-my dear uncle ten - pound note . [I]639-i wanted some money in a hurry , so [I]639-i took it . [I]639-i 've spent some of it . "[639-i]

" Oh , [I]639-i do n't know . But [I]639-i make up [my]639-i accounts every night . "[639-i]

" [Lass]1738-lass , "[74-james] said [he]74-james , staring firmly out of the window , " this wo n't do . [I]74-james let [ye]1738-lass know at once . This wunna ' do . "[74-james] [He]74-james was determined to be [master]640-master in [[his]74-james own house]641-his own house . [She]639-i also was determined to be master in [[his]74-james own house]641-his own house . Conflict was imminent .

" May [I]639-i ask what [you]74-james mean , [uncle]1867-uncle ? "[639-i]

[He]74-james hesitated . [He]74-james was not afraid of [her]639-i . But [he]74-james was afraid of [her]639-i dress - not of the material , but of the cut of it . But the aristocratic , insolent perfection of [Helen]79-helen 's gown gave [him]74-james pause .[74-james]

" Why did n't [you]639-i tell [me]74-james ? "[74-james] [he]74-james demanded .

" [I]639-i merely did n't think of it , "[639-i] [she]639-i said . " [I]639-i 've been very busy . "[639-i]

" [I]639-i 've been here over a week , "[639-i] said [she]639-i , " and [you]74-james 've given [me]639-i a pound and a postal order for ten shillings , which [I]639-i had to ask for . " [I]74-james gave [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt a pound a wik , "[74-james] [he]74-james observed .

" But think what [a good manager Mrs. Butt]1932-a good manager mrs. butt was ! "[639-i] [she]639-i said , with the sweetness of [a saint]643-a saint .

[He]74-james was accustomed to distributing satire , but not to receiving it . And , receiving this snowball full in the mouth , [he]74-james did not quite know what to do with it ; whether to pretend that [he]74-james had received nothing , or to call [a policeman]457-a policeman . [He]74-james ended by spluttering .

" It 's easy enough to ask for money when [you]639-i want it , "[74-james] [he]74-james said .

" [I]639-i hate asking for money , "[639-i] [she]639-i said . " [All women]1933-all women do . "[639-i]

" Then am [I]74-james to be inquiring every morning whether [you]639-i want money ? "[74-james] [he]74-james questioned , sarcastically .

" Certainly , [uncle]1867-uncle , "[639-i] [she]639-i answered . " How else are [you]1867-uncle to know ? "[639-i]

Difficult to credit that [that girl]645-that girl had been [an angel of light]646-an angel of light all the week , existing in [a paradise which [she]645-that girl had created for [herself]645-that girl]647-a paradise which she had created for herself , and for [him]74-james ! And now , to defend an action utterly indefensible , [she]645-that girl was employing a tone that might be compared to some fiendish instrumental device of [a dentist]648-a dentist .

But [James Ollerenshaw]74-james did not wish [his]74-james teeth stopped , nor yet extracted . [He]74-james had excellent teeth . And , in common with [all men who have never taken thirty consecutive repasts alone with [the same woman]650-the same woman]649-all men who have never taken thirty consecutive repasts alone with the same woman , [he]74-james knew how to treat [women]329-women , how to handle [them]329-women - the trout !

[He]74-james stood up . [He]74-james raised all [his]74-james body . [Helen]79-helen raised only [her]79-helen eyebrows .

" [Helen Rathbone]79-helen ! "[79-helen] Such was the exordium . As an exordium , it was faultless . But it was destined to remain a fragment . It goes down to history as a perfect fragment , like the beginning of a pagan temple that the death of gods has rendered superfluous .

For a dog - cart stopped in front of [the house]475-the house at that precise second , deposited [a lady of commanding mien]653-a lady of commanding mien , and dashed off again . [The lady]654-the lady opened [James]74-james 's gate and knocked at [James]74-james 's front door . [She]654-the lady could not be [a relative of [a tenant]656-a tenant]655-a relative of a tenant . [James]74-james was closely acquainted with all [[his]74-james tenants]611-his tenants , and [he]74-james had [none of that caliber]658-none of that caliber . Moreover , [Helen]79-helen had caused a small board to be affixed to the gate : " [Tenants]438-tenants will please go round to the back . "[79-helen]

" Bless [us]1936-us ! "[74-james] [he]74-james murmured , angrily . And , by force of habit , [he]74-james went and opened the door . Then [he]74-james recognised [the lady]654-the lady . [It]654-the lady was [Sarah Swetnam]107-sarah , [eldest child of [the large and tumultuously intellectual Swetnam family that lived in [a largish house]662-a largish house in a largish way higher up [the road]663-the road]661-the large and tumultuously intellectual swetnam family that lived in a largish house in a largish way higher up the road , and as to whose financial stability rumour always had something interesting to say]660-eldest child of the large and tumultuously intellectual swetnam family that lived in a largish house in a largish way higher up the road , and as to whose financial stability rumour always had something interesting to say .

" Is [Miss Rathbone]108-miss rathbone [here]1785-here ? "[654-the lady]

Before [he]74-james could reply , there was an ecstatic cry behind [him]74-james : " [Sally]107-sarah ! "[107-sarah] And another in front of [him]74-james : " [Nell]109-nell ! "[107-sarah]

In the very nick of time [he]74-james slipped aside , and thus avoided the inconvenience of being crushed to pulp between [two locomotives under full steam]664-two locomotives under full steam . It appeared that [they]665-they had not met for some years , [Sally]107-sarah having been in [London]4-london . The reunion was an affecting sight , and such a sight as had never before been witnessed in [[James]74-james 's house]666-james 's house . [The little room]667-the little room seemed to be full of [fashionable women]668-fashionable women , to be all gloves , frills , hat , parasol , veil , and whirling flowers ; also scent . [They]665-they kissed , through [Sally]107-sarah 's veil first , and then [she]107-sarah lifted the veil , and four vermilion lips clung together . [Sally]107-sarah was even taller than [Helen]79-helen , with a solid waist ; and older , more brazen . [They]665-they both sat down . [Fashionable women]668-fashionable women have a manner of sitting down quite different from that of [ordinary women]670-ordinary women , such as [the wives of [[James]74-james 's tenants]672-james 's tenants]671-the wives of james 's tenants . [They]668-fashionable women only touch the back of the chair at the top . [They]668-fashionable women do n't loll , but [they]668-fashionable women only escape lolling by dint of gracefulness . It is an affair of curves , slants , descents , nicely calculated . [They]668-fashionable women elaborately lead [your]673-you eye downwards over gradually increasing expanses , and naturally [you]673-you expect to see [their]668-fashionable women feet - and [you]673-you do n't see [their]668-fashionable women feet . The thing is apt to be disturbing to [unhabituated beholders]674-unhabituated beholders .

Then [fashionable women]668-fashionable women always begin [their]668-fashionable women conversation right off . There are no modest or shy or decently awkward silences at the start . [They]665-they slip into a conversation as a duck into water . In three minutes [Helen]79-helen had told [Sarah Swetnam]107-sarah everything about [her]79-helen leaving [the school]1908-the school , and about [[her]79-helen establishment]677-her establishment with [her]79-helen great - stepuncle . And [Sarah]107-sarah seemed delighted , and tapped the tiles of the floor with the tip of [her]107-sarah sunshade , and gazed splendidly over [the room]499-the room .

" And there are [your]107-sarah books there , [I]79-helen see ! "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said , in [her]79-helen positive , calm voice , pointing to a few hundred books that were stacked in a corner . " How lovely ! [You]107-sarah remember [you]107-sarah promised to lend [me]79-helen that book of [Thoreau]110-thoreau 's - what did [you]107-sarah call it ? - and [you]107-sarah never did ! "[79-helen]

" Next time [you]107-sarah come [I]79-helen 'll find it for [you]107-sarah , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen .

Next time [she]79-helen came ! This kind of visit would occur frequently , then ! [They]679-they were talking just as if [James Ollerenshaw]74-james had been in [Timbuctoo]26-timbuctoo , instead of by the mantelpiece , when [Sally]107-sarah suddenly turned on [him]74-james .

" It must be very nice for [you]74-james to have [Nell]109-nell like this ! "[107-sarah] [She]107-sarah addressed [him]74-james with a glowing smile .

[They]679-they had never been introduced ! A week ago [they]679-they had passed each other in [St. Luke's]21-st. luke's - square - square without a sign . Of [the Swetnam family]680-the swetnam family , [James]74-james " knew "[681-the father] [the father]681-the father alone , and [him]681-the father slightly . What chiefly impressed [him]74-james in [Sarah]107-sarah was [her]107-sarah nerve . [He]74-james said nothing ; [he]74-james was tongue - tied .

" It 's a great change for [you]74-james , "[107-sarah] proceeded [Sarah]107-sarah .

" Ay , "[74-james] [he]74-james agreed ; " it 's that . "[74-james]

Contents Chapter 10

A CALL

The next moment [the two fluffy women]682-the two fluffy women had decided , without in the least consulting [James]74-james , that [they]682-the two fluffy women would ascend to [[Helen]79-helen 's bedroom]683-helen 's bedroom to look at a hat which , [James]74-james was surprised to learn , [Helen]79-helen had seen in [Brunt]111-brunt 's window that morning and had bought on the spot . No wonder [she]79-helen had been in a hurry to go marketing ; no wonder [she]79-helen had spent ' some " of [his]74-james ten - pound note ! [He]74-james had seen hats in Brunt 's marked as high as two guineas but [he]74-james had not dreamt that such hats would ever enter [[his]74-james house]1938-his house . While [he]74-james had been labouring , collecting [his]74-james rents and arranging for repairs , throughout the length and the breadth of [Bursley]1-bursley and [Turnhill]2-turnhill , [she]79-helen , under pretence of marketing , had been flinging away ten - pound notes at [Brunt]111-brunt 's . The whole business was fantastic , simply and madly fantastic ; so fantastic that [he]74-james had not yet quite grasped the reality of it ! The whole business was unheard of . [He]74-james saw , with all the clearness of [his]74-james masculine intellect , that it must cease . The force with which [he]74-james decided within [himself]74-james that it must cease - and instanter ! - bordered upon the hysterical . As [he]74-james had said , plaintively , [he]74-james was [an oldish man]1923-an oldish man . [His]74-james habits , [his]74-james manners , and [his]74-james notions , especially [his]74-james notions about money , were fixed and set like plaster of [Paris]28-paris in a mould . [Helen]79-helen 's conduct was nothing less than dangerous . It might bring [him]74-james to a sudden death from heart disease . Happily , [he]74-james had had a very good week indeed with [his]74-james rents . [He]74-james trotted about all day on Mondays and on Tuesday mornings , gathering [his]74-james rents , and on Tuesday afternoons [he]74-james usually experienced the assuaged content of an alligator after the weekly meal . Otherwise there was no knowing what might not have been the disastrous consequences of [Helen]79-helen 's barefaced robbery and of [her]79-helen unscrupulous , unrepentant defence of that robbery . For days and days [he]684-his had imagined [himself]684-his in [heaven]1940-heaven with [a seraph who was also [a good cook]1942-a good cook]1941-a seraph who was also a good cook . [He]684-his had forty times congratulated [himself]684-his on catching [Helen]79-helen . And now ![79-helen]

But it must stop .

Then [he]684-his thought of the cooking . [His]684-his mouth remembered its first taste of the incomparable kidney omelette . What an ecstasy ! Still , a ten - pound note for even a kidney omelette jarred on the fineness of [his]684-his sense of values .

A feminine laugh - [Helen]79-helen 's - came down the narrow stairs and through [the kitchen]490-the kitchen . . . No , [the whole house]686-the whole house was altered , with [well - bred , distinguished women]687-well - bred , distinguished women 's laughter floating about the stairs like that .

[He]684-his called upon [[his]684-his lifelong friend]688-his lifelong friend and comforter - the concertina . That senseless thing of rosewood , ivory , ebony , mother - of - pearl , and leather was to [him]684-his what [a brother]689-a brother , a pipe , [a bull terrier]690-a bull terrier , [a trusted confidant]691-a trusted confidant , might have been to another [James]74-james . And now , in the accents of [the Hallelujah Chorus]692-the hallelujah chorus , it yielded to [his]684-his squeezings the secret and sublime solace which [men]331-men term poetry .

Then there was a second , and equally imperious , knock at the door .

[He]684-his loosed [his]684-his fingers from [[his]684-his friend]694-his friend , and opened the door .

[Mr. Emanuel Prockter]95-emanuel stood on the doorstep . [Mr. Emanuel Prockter]95-emanuel wore a beautiful blue suit , with a white waistcoat and pale gold tie ; yellow gloves , boots with pointed toes , a glossy bowler hat , a cane , and an eyeglass . [He]95-emanuel was [an impeccable young man]695-an impeccable young man , and the avowed delight of [[his]95-emanuel tailor]696-his tailor , whose bills were paid by [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter .

" Is [Miss Rathbone]108-miss rathbone at [home]1773-home ? "[95-emanuel] asked [Emanuel]95-emanuel , after a cough .

" [Helen]79-helen ? "[74-james]

" [Ye]95-emanuel - es . "[74-james]

" Thanks , [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james . What - er - fine weather [we]1945-we 're having ! "[74-james]

[James]74-james ignored this quite courteous and truthful remark . [He]74-james shut the door , went into [the kitchen]490-the kitchen , and called up the stairs : " [Helen]79-helen , [a young man]1946-a young man to see [ye]79-helen . "[74-james]

In [the bedroom]698-the bedroom , [Helen]79-helen and [Sarah Swetnam]107-sarah had exhausted the Brunt hat , and were spaciously at [sea]699-sea in an enchanted ocean of miscellaneous gossip such as is only possible between [two highly - educated women who scorn tittle - tattle]700-two highly - educated women who scorn tittle - tattle . [Helen]79-helen had [the back bedroom]701-the back bedroom ; partly because [the front bedroom]702-the front bedroom was [[her]79-helen uncle]703-her uncle 's , but partly also because [the back bedroom]701-the back bedroom was just as large as and much quieter than the other , and because [she]79-helen preferred [it]701-the back bedroom . There had been no difficulty about furniture . [[Helen]79-helen 's bedroom]683-helen 's bedroom was not " finished "[79-helen] ; nor , since [she]79-helen regarded [it]683-helen 's bedroom as [a temporary lodging]710-a temporary lodging rather than a permanent habitation , was [she]79-helen in a mind to finish it . Still , with [her]79-helen frocks dotted about , the hat on the four - post bed , and [her]79-helen silver - mounted brushes and manicure tools on the dressing - table , it had a certain stylishness . [Sarah]107-sarah shared the bed with the hat . [Helen]79-helen knelt at a trunk .

" Whatever made [you]79-helen think of coming to [Bursley]1-bursley ? "[107-sarah] [Sarah]107-sarah questioned .

It was at this point that the voice of [James Ollerenshaw]74-james announced [a young man]1946-a young man .

The remainder of that afternoon was like a bewildering dream to [James Ollerenshaw]74-james . [[His]1946-a young man front room]580-his front room seemed to be crowded with a multitude of peacocks , that would have been more at [home]1773-home under the sun of [[Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter 's lawns up at [Hillport]23-hillport]715-mrs. prockter 's lawns up at hillport . "[717-three persons] And [he]1946-a young man had to sit and listen to [them]717-three persons , and even to answer coherently when spoken to . [Emanuel Prockter]95-emanuel was brilliant . [He]95-emanuel had put [his]95-emanuel hat on one chair and [his]95-emanuel cane across another , and [he]95-emanuel conversed with [ducal facility]719-ducal facility . The two things about [him]95-emanuel that puzzled [the master of [the house]475-the house]720-the master of the house were - first , why [he]95-emanuel was not , at such an hour , engaged in at any rate the pretence of earning [his]95-emanuel living ; and , second , why [he]95-emanuel did not take [his]95-emanuel gloves off . No notion of work seemed to exist in the minds of [the three]722-the three . [They]722-the three chattered of tennis , novels , music , and particularly of [amateur operatic societies]723-amateur operatic societies . [James]74-james acquired the information that [Emanuel]95-emanuel was famous as [a singer of songs]724-a singer of songs . And that led to [the Old Oak Tree tea - house]728-the old oak tree tea - house in [Bond - street]31-bond - street , where , not to be beaten by [Emanuel]95-emanuel , [Sarah Swetnam]107-sarah had lately been .

" Suppose [we]730-we have tea , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen .

And [she]79-helen picked up a little brass bell which stood on the central table and tinkled it . [James]74-james had not noticed the bell . It was one of the many little changes that [Helen]79-helen had introduced . Each change by itself was a nothing - what is one small bell in [a house]729-a house ? - yet in the mass they amounted to much . The bell was obviously new . [She]79-helen must have bought it ; but [she]79-helen had not mentioned it to [him]74-james . And how cou1d [they]730-we all sit at the tiny table in [the kitchen]490-the kitchen ? Moreover , [he]74-james had no fancy for entertaining [the whole town of [Bursley]1-bursley]732-the whole town of bursley to meals . However , the immediate prospect of tea produced in [James]74-james a feeling of satisfaction , even though [he]74-james remained in perfect ignorance of the methods by which [Helen]79-helen meant to achieve the tea . [She]79-helen had rung the bell , and gone on talking , as if the tea would cook itself and walk in on its hind legs and ask to be eaten .

Then [the new servant]733-the new servant entered with a large tray . [James]74-james had never seen [such a servant]734-such a servant , [a servant]623-a servant so entirely new . [She]79-helen was wearing a black frock and various parts of the frock , and the top of [her]79-helen head , were covered with stiffly - starched white linen - or was it cotton ? [Her]79-helen apron , which had two pockets , was more elaborate than an antimacassar . [Helen]79-helen coolly instructed [her]79-helen to place the tray on [his]74-james desk ; which [she]79-helen did , brushing irreverently aside a number of rent books .

On the tray there was nothing whatever to eat but a dozen slices of the thinnest conceivable bread and butter .

[Helen]79-helen rose . [Emanuel]95-emanuel also rose .

[Helen]79-helen poured out the tea . [Emanuel]95-emanuel took a cup and saucer in one hand and the plate of bread and butter in the other , and ceremoniously approached [Sarah Swetnam]107-sarah . [Sarah]107-sarah accepted the cup and saucer , delicately chose a piece of bread and butter , and lodged it on [her]107-sarah saucer , and went on talking .

[Emanuel]95-emanuel returned to the table , and , reladen , approached [old Jimmy]74-james , and [old Jimmy]74-james had to lodge a piece of bread and butter on [his]74-james saucer . Then [Emanuel]95-emanuel removed [his]95-emanuel gloves , and in a moment [they]736-they were all drinking tea and nibbling bread and butter .

What a fall was this from kidney omelettes ! And four had struck ! Did [Helen]79-helen expect [[her]79-helen uncle]703-her uncle to make [his]703-her uncle tea off a slice of bread and butter that weighed about two drachms ?

When the alleged tea was over [James]74-james got on [his]74-james feet , and silently slid into [the kitchen]490-the kitchen . The fact was that [Emanuel Prockter]95-emanuel and the manikin airs of [Emanuel Prockter]95-emanuel made [him]74-james positively sick . [He]74-james had not been in [the kitchen]490-the kitchen more than a minute before [he]74-james was aware of amazing matters in the conversation .

" Yes , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen ; " it 's small . "[79-helen]

" [I]79-helen 've always lived in [a small house]1963-a small house , just as [I]79-helen 've taught six hours a day in [a school]1966-a school . But not because [I]79-helen wanted to . " [I]107-sarah was just saying how quaint and pretty [[your]742-the company house]1970-your house is , "[107-sarah] said [Sarah]107-sarah , and [she]107-sarah rose to depart . More kissings , flutterings , swishings ! [Emanuel]95-emanuel bowed .

[Emanuel]95-emanuel followed [Miss Swetnam]116-miss swetnam in a few minutes . [Helen]79-helen accompanied [him]95-emanuel to the gate , where [she]79-helen stayed a little while talking to [him]95-emanuel . [James]74-james was in the blackest gloom .

" And now , [[you]95-emanuel dear old thing]1971-you dear old thing , "[79-helen] said [Helen]79-helen , vivaciously bustling into [the house]475-the house , " [you]95-emanuel shall have [your]95-emanuel tea . [You]95-emanuel 've behaved like [a perfect angel]1972-a perfect angel . "[79-helen]

And [she]79-helen kissed [him]95-emanuel on the cheek , very excitedly , as [he]95-emanuel thought .

[She]79-helen gave [him]95-emanuel another kidney omelette for [his]95-emanuel tea . It was even more adorable than the former one . When tea was over [she]79-helen retired [upstairs]1919-upstairs , and remained in retirement for ages . [She]79-helen descended at a quarter to eight , with [her]79-helen hat and gloves on . It appeared to [him]95-emanuel that [her]79-helen eyes were inflamed .

" [I]79-helen 'm going out , "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said , with no further explanation .

And out [she]79-helen went , leaving [the old man]372-the old man , stricken daft by too many sensations , to collect [his]372-the old man wits .

[He]372-the old man had not even been to [the bank]746-the bank !

And the greatest sensation of all the nightmarish days was still in reserve for [him]95-emanuel . At a quarter - past eight [some one]1863-some one knocked at the door . [He]95-emanuel imagined [himself]95-emanuel ready for anything ; but [he]95-emanuel was not ready for the apparition which met [him]95-emanuel on the threshold .

[Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter , of [Hillport]23-hillport , asked to be admitted !

Contents Chapter 11

ANOTHER CALL

[Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter was compelled to ask for admission , because [James]74-james , struck moveless and speechless by the extraordinary sight of [her]79-helen , offered no invitation to enter . [He]74-james merely stood in front of the half - opened door .

" May [I]79-helen come in , [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james ? "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said , very urbanely . " [I]79-helen hope [you]74-james will excuse this very informal call . [I]79-helen 've altered [my]79-helen dinner hour in order to pay it . "[79-helen]

And [she]79-helen smiled . The smile seemed to rouse [him]74-james from a spell .

" Come in , [missis]1973-missis , do ! "[74-james] [he]74-james conjured [her]79-helen , warmly .

[He]74-james was [James]74-james ; [he]74-james was even [Jimmy]74-james ; but [he]74-james was also [a man]271-a man , very much [a man]271-a man , though the fact had only recently begun to impress itself on [him]74-james . [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter , while [a dowager]751-a dowager - portly , possibly fussy , perhaps slightly comic to [a younger generation]752-a younger generation - was still considerably younger than [James]74-james . With [her]79-helen rich figure , [her]79-helen excellent complexion , [her]79-helen carefully - cherished hair , and [her]79-helen apparel , [she]79-helen was a woman to captivate [a man of sixty , whose practical experience of thesex extended over nine days]753-a man of sixty , whose practical experience of thesex extended over nine days .

" Thank [you]74-james , "[79-helen] said [she]79-helen , gratefully .

[He]74-james shut the front door , as if [he]74-james were shutting a bird in a cage ; and [he]74-james also shut the door leading to [the kitchen]490-the kitchen - a door which had not been shut since the kitchen fire smoked in the celebrated winter of 1897 . [She]79-helen sat down at once in the easy - chair .

" Ah ! "[79-helen] [she]79-helen exclaimed , in relief . And then [she]79-helen began to fan [herself]79-helen with a fan which was fastened to [her]79-helen person by a chain that might have moored [a steamer]755-a steamer .

[James]74-james , searching about for something else to do while [he]74-james was collecting [his]74-james forces , drew the blind and lighted the gas . But it was not yet dark .

" [I]79-helen wonder what [you]74-james will think of [me]79-helen , calling like this ? "[79-helen] [she]79-helen said , with a sardonic smile .

It was apparent that , whatever [he]74-james thought of [her]79-helen , [she]79-helen would not be disturbed or abashed . [She]79-helen was utterly at [her]79-helen ease . [She]79-helen could not , indeed , have recalled the moment when [she]79-helen had not been at [her]79-helen ease . [She]79-helen sat in [the front room]1881-the front room with all the external symptoms of being at [home]1773-home . This was what chiefly surprised [James Ollerenshaw]74-james in [[his]74-james grand guests]758-his grand guests - [they]758-his grand guests all took [[his]74-james front room]580-his front room for granted . [They]758-his grand guests betrayed no emotion at its smallness or its plainness , or its eccentricities . [He]74-james would somehow have expected [them]758-his grand guests to signify , overtly or covertly , that [that kind of room]760-that kind of room was not the kind of room to which [they]758-his grand guests were accustomed .

" Anyhow , [I]74-james 'm glad to see [ye]84-mrs. prockter , [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter , "[74-james] [James]74-james returned .

A speech which did not in the least startle [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter , who was thoroughly used to [people]304-people being glad to see [her]84-mrs. prockter . But it startled [James]74-james . [He]74-james had uttered it instinctively ; it was the expression of an instinctive gladness which took hold of [him]74-james and employed [his]74-james tongue on its own account , and which rose superior even to [his]74-james extreme astonishment at the visit . [He]74-james was glad to see [her]84-mrs. prockter . [She]84-mrs. prockter was stout and magnificent , in [her]84-mrs. prockter silk and [her]84-mrs. prockter ribbons . [He]74-james felt that [he]74-james preferred [stout women]762-stout women to thin ; and that , without being aware of it , [he]74-james had always preferred [stout women]762-stout women to thin . It was a question of taste . [He]74-james certainly preferred [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter to [Sarah Swetnam]107-sarah . [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter 's smile was the smile of [a benevolently cynical creature whose studies in human nature had reached the advanced stage]764-a benevolently cynical creature whose studies in human nature had reached the advanced stage . [James]74-james was reassured by this , for it avoided the necessity for " nonsense . "[84-mrs. prockter] . . . Yes , [she]84-mrs. prockter was decidedly better under a roof and a gas - jet than [inthe street]765-inthe street .

" May [I]84-mrs. prockter ask if [[your]74-james niece]1974-your niece is in ? "[84-mrs. prockter] [she]84-mrs. prockter said , in a low voice .

" [She]1974-your niece is n't . "[84-mrs. prockter]

[He]74-james had been sure that [she]84-mrs. prockter had called about [Helen]79-helen , if not to see [Helen]79-helen . But there was a conspiratorial accent in [her]84-mrs. prockter question for which [he]74-james was unprepared . So [he]74-james sat down at last .

" Well , "[84-mrs. prockter] said [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter , " [I]84-mrs. prockter 'm not sorry [she]84-mrs. prockter is n't . The horror of [his]772-his complicated situation displayed itself suddenly to [James]74-james . [He]74-james who had always led a calm , unworried life , was about to be shoved into the very midst of [a hullabaloo of [women]329-women and [fools]775-fools]773-a hullabaloo of women and fools .

" Oh ! "[84-mrs. prockter]

" [She]1997-your stepniece is ! "[74-james] [James]74-james agreed with simple heartiness of conviction .

But [he]74-james kept this pleasure to [himself]74-james .

" Nowt ! "[74-james] [he]74-james said , drily .

[He]74-james spoke to [her]776-her as [one sensible person]778-one sensible person speaks to [another sensible person in [the Five Towns]193-the five towns]779-another sensible person in the five towns . "[776-her] But here [she]776-her was declaring that [Helen]79-helen was too good for [[her]776-her stepson]444-her stepson . If [his]74-james pride had momentarily suffered , through a misconception , it was now in the full vigour of its strength .

" [You]74-james think [we]2027-we can do nothing ? "[776-her] [she]776-her said , reflectively , and leant forward on [her]776-her chair , towards [him]74-james , as if struck by [his]74-james oracular wisdom .

" What can [us]2027-we do ? "[776-her]

" [You]74-james might praise [Emanuel]95-emanuel to [her]776-her - urge [her]776-her on . "[776-her] [She]776-her fixed [him]74-james with [her]776-her eye .

" [I]776-her must think it over "[776-her] - [she]776-her emerged from [her]776-her reflections . " [I]776-her feel much easier now [I]776-her 've told [you]74-james all about it . [He]74-james saw clearly all the perils of such a course , but [his]74-james instinct seized [him]74-james again .

[Helen]79-helen came [home]1773-home about ten o'clock , and went direct to bed . Never before had [James Ollerenshaw]74-james felt like [a criminal]786-a criminal , but as [Helen]79-helen 's eyes dwelt for a moment on [his]74-james in bidding [him]74-james goodnight , [he]74-james could scarcely restrain the blush of [the evildoer]787-the evildoer . And [him]74-james sixty ! Turn which way [he]74-james would [he]74-james saw nothing but worry . What an incredible day [he]74-james had lived through ! And how astounding was human existence !

Contents Chapter 12

BREAKFAST

[He]74-james had an unsatisfactory night - that is to say , in the matter of sleep . In respect of sagacity [he]74-james rose richer than [he]74-james had lain down . [He]74-james had daily perceived , about three a.m. , that [he]74-james was moving too much in circles which were foreign to [him]74-james , and which called [him]74-james " [Jimmy]74-james . "[74-james] And at five a.m. , when [the first workmen]788-the first workmen 's car woke bumpily the echoes of [the morn]789-the morn , [he]74-james had perceived that [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter 's plan for separating [Emanuel]95-emanuel and [Helen]79-helen by bringing [them]790-them together was not a wise plan . Of course , [Helen]79-helen must not marry [Emanuel Prockter]95-emanuel . The notion of such a union was ludicrous . In spite of all the worry [she]79-helen was heaping upon [him]74-james , [he]74-james did not see any urgent reason why [she]79-helen should marry [anybody]517-anybody . But the proper method of nipping the orange - blossom in the bud was certainly to have a plain chat with [Helen]79-helen , one of those plain chats which can only occur , successfully , between [plain , common - sense persons]792-plain , common - sense persons . [He]74-james was convinced that , notwithstanding [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter 's fears , [Helen]79-helen had not for an instant thought of [Emanuel]95-emanuel as [a husband]793-a husband . It was inconceivable that [she]79-helen , [a girl so utterly sensible]794-a girl so utterly sensible , should have done so . And yet - [girls]1737-girls ! And [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter was [no fool]796-no fool , come to think of it . [A sterling creature]797-a sterling creature . Not of [[his]74-james world]718-his world , but nevertheless - At this point [he]74-james uneasily dozed .

However , [he]74-james determined to talk with [Helen]79-helen that morning at breakfast . [He]74-james descended at half - past seven , as usual , full of a diplomatic intention to talk to [Helen]79-helen . [She]79-helen was wholly sensible ; [she]79-helen was [a person to whom [you]800-you could talk]799-a person to whom you could talk . Still , tact would be needed . Lack of sleep had rendered [his]74-james nervous system such that [he]74-james would have preferred to receive tact rather than to give it . But , happily , [he]74-james was [a self - controlled man]801-a self - controlled man .

[His]74-james post , which lay scattered on the tiles at the foot of the front door , did not interest [him]74-james . [He]74-james put it aside , in its basket . Nor could [he]74-james work , according to [his]74-james custom , at [his]74-james accounts . Even the sight of the unfilled - in credit - slips for [the bank]746-the bank did not spur [him]74-james to industry . There can be no doubt that [he]74-james was upset .

[He]74-james walked across [the room]499-the room to the piles of [Helen]79-helen 's books against the wall , and in sheer absence of mind picked one up , and sat on a chair , on which [he]74-james had never before sat , and began to read the volume .

Then the hurried , pretentious striking of the kitchen clock startled [him]74-james . Half - an - hour had passed in a moment . [He]74-james peeped into [the kitchen]490-the kitchen . Not a sign of breakfast ! Not a sign of [the new servant]733-the new servant , with [her]733-the new servant starched frills ! And for thirty years [he]74-james had breakfasted at eight o'clock precisely .

And no [Helen]79-helen ! Was [Helen]79-helen laughing at [him]74-james ? Was [Helen]79-helen treating [him]74-james as [an individual of no importance]806-an individual of no importance ? It was unimaginable that [his]74-james breakfast should be late . If [anybody]517-anybody thought that [he]74-james was going to - No ! [he]74-james must not give way to righteous resentment . Diplomacy ! Tact ! Forbearance !

But [he]74-james would just go up to [[Helen]79-helen 's room]808-helen 's room and rap , and tell [her]79-helen of the amazing and awful state of things on the ground - floor . As a fact , [she]79-helen [herself]79-helen was late . At that moment [she]79-helen appeared .

" Good - morning , [uncle]1867-uncle . "[79-helen]

[She]79-helen was cold , prim , cut off like [China]118-china from human intercourse by a wall .

" Th ' [servant]2039-servant has na ' come , "[74-james] said [he]74-james , straining to be tolerant and amicable . [He]74-james did [his]74-james best to keep a grieved astonishment out of [his]74-james voice ; but [he]74-james could not .

" Oh ! "[79-helen] [she]79-helen murmured , calmly . It was nothing to [her]79-helen , then , that [James]74-james 's life should be turned upside down ! And [she]79-helen added , with icy detachment : " [I]79-helen 'm not surprised . [You]1867-uncle 'll never get [servants]1853-servants to be prompt in the morning when [they]1853-servants do n't sleep in [the house]475-the house . And there 's no room for [Georgiana]119-georgiana to sleep in [the house]475-the house . "[79-helen]

[Georgiana]119-georgiana ! Preposterous name !

" [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt was always prompt . [I]74-james 'll say that for [her]97-mrs. butt , "[74-james] [he]74-james replied .

This , as [he]74-james immediately recognised , was a failure in tact on [his]74-james part . So when [she]79-helen said quickly : " [I]79-helen 'm sure [Mrs. Butt]97-mrs. butt would be delighted to come back if [you]74-james asked [her]97-mrs. butt , "[79-helen] [he]74-james said nothing .

What staggered [his]74-james intellect and [his]74-james knowledge of human nature was that [she]79-helen remained absolutely unmoved by this appalling , unprecedented , and complete absence of any sign of breakfast at after eight o'clock .

Just then [Georgiana]119-georgiana came . [She]119-georgiana had a key to the back door , and entered [the house]475-the house by way of [the scullery]491-the scullery .

" Good - morning , [Georgiana]119-georgiana , "[79-helen] [Helen]79-helen greeted [her]119-georgiana , going into [the scullery]491-the scullery - much more kindly than [she]79-helen had greeted [[her]79-helen uncle]703-her uncle . Instead of falling on [Georgiana]119-georgiana and slaying [her]119-georgiana , [she]79-helen practically embraced [her]119-georgiana .

A gas cooking - stove is a wondrous gift of Heaven . [You]813-you do not have to light it with yesterday 's paper , damp wood , and the remains of last night 's fire . In twelve minutes not merely was the breakfast ready , but [the kitchen]490-the kitchen was dusted , and there was a rose in a glass next to the bacon . [James]74-james had calmed [himself]74-james by reading the book , and the period of waiting had really been very short . As [he]74-james fronted the bacon and the flower , [Helen]79-helen carefully shut the scullery door . The Manchester Guardian lay to the left of [his]74-james plate . Thoughtful ! Altogether it was not so bad .

Further , [she]79-helen smiled in handing [him]74-james [his]74-james tea . [She]79-helen , too , [he]74-james observed , must have slept ill . [Her]79-helen agreeable face was drawn . But [her]79-helen blue - and - white - striped dress was impeccably put on . It was severe , and yet very smooth . It suited [her]79-helen mood . It also suited [his]74-james . [They]815-they faced [each other]456-each other , as [self - controlled people]817-self - controlled people do face [each other]456-each other at breakfast after white nights , disillusioned , tremendously sensible , wise , gently cynical , seeing [the world]220-the world with steady and just orbs .

" [I]74-james 've been reading one o ' [your]79-helen books , [lass]1738-lass , "[74-james] [he]74-james began , with superb amiability . " It 's pretty near as good as a newspaper . Contents Chapter 13

THE WORLD

A few days later [James Ollerenshaw]74-james was alone in [the front room]1881-the front room , checking various accounts for repairs of property in [Turnhill]2-turnhill , when twin letters fell into the quietude of [the apartment]829-the apartment . [The postman]830-the postman - [the famous old postman of [Bursley]1-bursley , who on fine summer days surmounted the acute difficulty of tender feet by delivering mails in worsted slippers]831-the famous old postman of bursley , who on fine summer days surmounted the acute difficulty of tender feet by delivering mails in worsted slippers - had swiftly pushed the letters , as usual , through the slit in the door ; but , nevertheless , [their]832-they advent had somehow the air of magic , as , indeed , the advent of letters always had . [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james glanced curiously from [his]74-james chair , over [his]74-james spectacles , at the letters as they lay dead on the floor . [Their]832-they singular appearance caused [him]825-he to rise at once and pick them up . [They]832-they were sealed with a green seal , and addressed in a large and haughty hand - one to [Helen]79-helen and the other to [himself]825-he . Obviously [they]832-they came from [the world]220-the world which referred to [him]825-he as " [Jimmy]74-james . "[825-he] [He]825-he was not used to being thrilled by mere envelopes , but now [he]825-he became conscious of a slight quickening of pulsation . [He]825-he opened [his]825-he own envelope - the paper was more like a blanket than paper , and might have been made from the material of [a child]834-a child 's untearable picture - book . [He]825-he had to use a stout paper - knife , and when [he]825-he did get into the envelope [he]825-he felt like [a burglar]835-a burglar .

[The discerning and shrewd ancient]836-the discerning and shrewd ancient had guessed the contents . [He]825-he had feared , and [he]825-he had also hoped , that the contents would comprise an invitation to [[Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter 's house at [Hillport]23-hillport]837-mrs. prockter 's house at hillport . [They]832-they did ; and more than that . The signature was [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter 's , and [she]84-mrs. prockter had written [him]825-he a four - page letter . " [[My]84-mrs. prockter dear]2065-my dear [Mr. Ollerenshaw]74-james . "[84-mrs. prockter] " Believe [me]84-mrs. prockter , [yours]74-james most cordially and sincerely , [Flora Prockter]121-flora prockter . "[84-mrs. prockter]

[Flora]121-flora prockter !

The strangest thing , perhaps , in all this strange history is that [he]825-he thought the name suited [her]84-mrs. prockter .

[He]825-he had no intention of accepting the invitation . Not exactly ! But [he]825-he enjoyed receiving it . It constituted a unique event in [his]825-he career . And the wording of it was very agreeable . [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter proceeded thus : " In pursuance of [our]838-our plan "[84-mrs. prockter] - [our]838-our plan ! - " [I]84-mrs. prockter am also inviting [[your]74-james niece]1974-your niece . [James]74-james had once heard [Emanuel Prockter]95-emanuel sing , at a concert given in aid of something which deserved every discouragement , and [he]74-james agreed with [Mrs. Prockter]84-mrs. prockter ; not that [he]74-james pretended to know anything about singing .

[He]74-james sat down again , to compose a refusal to the invitation ; but before [he]74-james had written more than a few words it had transformed itself into an acceptance .
